I understood by that, that they wanted to know whether the persons were in Newgate; I promised the mob I would go in and come out again, and give them a fair answer; upon that the prisoner with two or three others said that if I would go in they would guard the door (the door at that time was fast) and see that no mischief should happen to me.

The purpose you were to go in for was to enquire if the rioters were out? - Exactly so. Whilst I stood upon the steps, before the turnkey had opened the door, I heard the prisoners with some others cry out for the engines to play, and they did so before I went in.

This was before you brought out any answer whether the rioters were out? - It was before I brought out any answer. I went in; the prisoner with others called out, let the engines play. I only desired the mob to suffer the engines to play that I might go in. In the course of eight or ten minutes I came out again and stood upon the steps of the door and told them that the rioters were all out; in the mean time I desired Pitt to secure the arms in the right hand of the lodge before I would I suffer the door to be opened. When I came the prisoner at the bar with others was standing on the steps telling them the rioters were out I saw the prisoner and the party that conducted me up going quietly away. That is all I know.

Counsel for the Prisoner. Mr. Alderman Wooldridge, I did not want this long story, I only meant to ask one single question, did you at all see the prisoner active or doing any thing in the mob? - If I have not declared the contrary, I do not know what I have said; for I have said that he was a peaceable person, who made way for me through the mob up to the door, and protected me while I was there; I thought him the most peaceable spectator that was there. I shall never think any story too long in any information that I can give for a man in his situation, nor too tedious for a court to hear.

PHILIP TOWNSEND
sworn.

I have known the prisoner six years; he has born an extraordinary good character. When his late master left the coffee-house, I meant to make application for him, being a favourite, to continue the business; several gentlemen offered 600 l. a piece for him to continue the tavern.

JOHN DICKERS
sworn.
I have known him eighteen or nineteen years; he has an exceeding good character.

Mr.
THOMAS HILT
sworn.

I live at Brighthelmstone. I have known the prisoner from a boy, but these last three years I have not had much knowledge of him from that time to this summer; he was a servant in the house I am partner in; I thought him a very good character, or I should not have kept him a servant three summers.
Mr. CREASER sworn.

I have known him three or four years. I live in Soho-square. He has an unexceptionable character, to my knowledge, from the masters he has served, and from a respectable person. I have known him long; he has borne an unexceptionable character.
Mr. WOOD sworn.
I have known him four or five years; he has a most unexceptionable character.

JOSEPH WEADEN
sworn.
I have known him by going backwards and forwards two or three years. He has a very good character by all account.

THOMAS LAW
sworn.
I have known him six years; he bore a very good character, he was an exceeding good waiter, very diligent in his business, and very honest.

ROGER GILL
sworn.
I keep the Star and Garter in Pall Mall: I have known him between two and three years; he has a general good character; he is spoken well of by every body who knows him.

GUILTY (
Death .)
Tried by the Second London Jury before Mr. Justice ASHHURST.
(He was humbly recommended by the Jury to his Majesty's mercy.)

397.
GEORGE SIMS
was indicted for
that he together with five hundred other persons and more, did unlawfully, riotously, and tumultuously assemble, on the 6th of June , to the disturbance of the publick peace, and did begin to demolish and pull down the dwelling-house of
Richard Akerman
, against the form of the statute, &c.

JOHN PITT
sworn.
I am servant to Mr. Akerman.

Was you at Mr. Akerman's at the time the mob came to Newgate
? - I was. On the 6th of June, at about seven o'clock at night we saw a vast concourse of people coming down to Newgate; they halloo'd Newgate a-hoy. The prisoner and some others came up to the great gate, down the Old Bailey; he swore a desperate oath that he would have the gates down; he either d - d his eyes, or d - d his blood he would have the gates down. Then they began at the gates, some with sledge hammers, and others with pick-axes; the prisoner had a large stick. I called to him because I had known him for some years; I said, Very well,
George
the tripe man, I shall mark you in particular. I had known him six or seven years. Then he went towards Mr. Akerman's house.
Was any mischief done to the gate or the hatch? - When they found they could not break the gate, they piled Mr. Akerman's goods up against it, and set them on fire.
Was any thing done at the hatch before you went away? - Some of the stones, part of the side of the hatch, were broken away.

You do not know then what was done to Mr. Akerman's house? - I saw the feathers fly; they had got some of Mr. Akerman's goods out, and they continued throwing them out; then they set them against the gate and set them on fire, and they would have burnt those gates down, but we kept throwing water against them to cool them, to keep the lead from melting, and letting the hinges out. Then Mr. Akerman's house was set on fire, that burnt into our fore lodge and into the chapel, and set the different wards on fire.
Are you or not sure that the prisoner is the person of whom you have been speaking? - I am positive he is the person; I know him as well as I know my own brother.
Prisoner. I beg the favour of your lordship to ask the witness the questions I have here upon a piece of paper.
Court. Let the paper be handed up to me and I will put the questions.
How long have you known the prisoner? - About seven years.

Had not you been in company with him some little time before the fire happened, in the Strand, and treated him with some punch? - I treated him with some milk punch, that was some months before; it was not in the Strand, it was in one of the bye-streets, near Clare-market.

Would you have thought him from his former behaviour a likely man to be concerned in mobs of this kind? - I have known him some time; he has always been forward in any quarrels in the streets or mobs.
At what hour were the keys of Newgate given up? - We never gave them up.
When were they demanded? - About seven o'clock they demanded them.
Was the prisoner there at the time when the keys were demanded? - He was one of the first who came up to the gate to demand their being opened.
Did you give him the key? - I gave no key.
You knew where the prisoner lived and might be found? - I did not know where he lived.
Did not you know where he carried on his business and might be found? - I knew he lived in Westminster. I met him one morning accidentally as I was going towards Clare-market.
How long after the 6th of June was it when you took him up? - I believe a week after.
Was it not nine days after? - I think it was the 15th of June when I took him up.

How came it to be so long before you apprehended him? - We were so busy that I had no time to look after him, I did not care to make any enquiry after him left he should get off. I knew we should find him.
Were you looking for him when you met him in the Strand, or was it by accident? - I was going up into St. James's-market and met him by accident.
Did you go to Westminster, or any of your friends and prevent any persons from offering bail for him? - Never.
Or say a thousand pounds would not bail him? - No, he served me with notice of bail. I showed it my master, Mr. Akerman.
When you took him up did not you know there was a reward offered? - No.
Did not you know of the king's proclamation? - I did not take him for the reward.
Did not you know there was a reward promised? - I did not know that there was for him.
Did not you know there was a reward? - I had heard of it.
Do you claim the reward? - No; I would not have any reward.
Do you disclaim any reward? - I do; I do not want any reward.
Jury. Did you mention this man as one concerned in the riot? - Yes, I did.
You say you have known him five or six years? - Yes.
Counsel for the Crown. It has already been proved that Mr. Akerman's house was demolished that night, I suppose I need not call the witnesses to prove that.
Jury. No, there is no occasion.
PRISONER's DEFENCE.
It is very unlikely that I should ask such a question of him when I knew no-body else but him in the jail. There are two other persons who remember my calling out to him though they did not know him.

Mr.
RICHARD AKERMAN
sworn.

Did the witness tell you any thing about the prisoner at the bar, and when? - I think it was the next day that he told me there was one man he knew very well,
George
the tripe-man, he called him.

WILLIAM SHEPHERD
sworn.
You are a servant of Mr. Akerman? - Yes.
Was you at the main gate at the time the mob were attempting to force themselves in? - I was.

Was
John Pitt
there? - He was.
Did he say any thing to any person on the outside of the gate? - The mob who were assembled came to demand the keys of the jail, for the prisoners to be delivered out; he was with me.
Did Pitt say any thing to any one of the mob? - He spoke to several, so did I too.

Did he say any thing to any one in particular? - In regard to charging my memory to any thing of that sort, I cannot particularly say; I know he spoke to several at particular times, but I was backwards and forwards.
Court. You do not recollect any particular person whom he spoke to? - I saw a great many there whom I should remember again if I saw them; I believe he spoke to a grea many particular persons.
Court. Do you recollect any particular person he spoke to? - I wish to say no more than I know.
Then you do not recollect any particular person, only that he spoke to several people? - I cannot say as to any person in particular.
Jury. Did you hear him say he knew any one person in particular? - Yes.
When? - Two or three days after.

What did he say then? - He told me he new one
George
the tripe-man; as to his sir-name, he did not particularly mention.
Court. You say the people came up to the gate? - Yes a great many.
Did you see the prisoner there? - I cannot charge my memory, I believe I saw his face, but I cannot say positively.
Jury to Mr. Akerman. Is that man a constant attendant on the gate or only occasionally.
Mr. Akerman. There are three of them attend occasionally, they take it by turns.
BARNWELL MALE sworn.

Was you at the great gate of Newgate when the mob were endeavouring to force it? - Yes. I stood by
John Pitt
all the while he was there.

Did he say any thing to any one of the mob? - Yes, he said very well, you Mr.
George
the tripe-man, I know you very well, and I will mark you. That person was, I believe, the prisoner at the bar, though he was in another dress then than he is now.
What did the person to whom Pitt spoke do upon being so called to? - I do not know; I saw him near the great gate at the time.
Jury. Had that man any thing in his hand at that time? - I cannot say whether he had or no.
For the Prisoner.

GEORGE LACAM
sworn.

Were you with the prisoner when he went to Newgate that night? - I was; it was about seven o'clock. I went with him from the end of Newgate-street; I met him at the end of Newgate-street, about seven in the evening. We stood together facing Mr. Akerman's house for, I believe, five minutes, then I missed him, but I met him again in about ten minutes after at the end of Fleet-market; I went away about a quarter after seven; I do not think I staid above a quarter of an hour in all.

What became of him after that? - I do not know, I parted with him then and wished him a good night; he was going towards Charing-cross; he crossed over directly when I bid him good night, and I did not see him again at all.
Was the street much crowded? - Very much.
How did he behave himself when you saw him opposite Mr. Akerman's house? - He behaved very quiet only just looked on as I did myself; he did not offer to throw any thing or break any windows.
You did not see him do any mischief? - No, none at all.
You met him in Newgate-street, which way was he going? - He was coming towards Newgate; I said there was a great mob; he said they were going to release the prisoners.

Had they begun to demolish Newgate when you came there? - They were thumping against the gate with a handspike; I came from Newgate-street, went down the Old Bailey, all along by Newgate, and met him again in Fleet-street.
What character has the prisoner borne since you knew him? - He lived servant with Mr. Smith, the tripe-man, in St. James's market; I know nothing bad of him, he is but a flight acquaintance of mine.

JOHN CROFTS
sworn.
I know the prisoner very well; he lodges in the house of Mrs. Howell, where I lodge.
Where is Mrs. Howell to-day? - She is now very ill in bed at home, and is not able to come here; she has attended this week, and last week too.
Were you at home on the evening that Newgate was burnt? - I was.
What time? - At eight in the evening, I came from work; the prisoner came home about a quarter after eight o'clock.
How came you to recollect the time particularly? - Sometimes I work till eight, sometimes till half after eight; we have a clock upon the stairs, it was then a quarter after eight o'clock.
What became of the prisoner afterwards? - I did not see him, he went to his apartment; his room is on the same floor with mine.
You do not know whether he came down again? - No, I saw no more of him.
How do you recollect that it was that particular night? - It was on the 6th of June. I am sure it was the night that Newgate was on fire, because I heard the people talk of it.

Do you remember any thing particular that passed that evening after the prisoner came home? - I believe there might be a few words between him and his wife, as most people who are married often have, I know that case too much myself.
Was it above or below? - I cannot say whether it was above or below; I know they had words that evening, about his wife being out at work.

Do you know
Sarah Davis
? - She is servant to Mr. Davis, a publican.
Does he serve your lodgings with beer? - Yes.
Did you see her there that night? - Yes, between eight and nine o'clock.

SARAH DAVIS
sworn.
How old are you? - Sixteen last April. I am servant to Mr. Davis, a publican.

Do you remember the evening when New-gate was burnt down? - Yes. I carried the prisoner a pint of beer home about eight o'clock in the evening. He then paid me for that pint, and a pot he had at dinner.

(The prisoner called
Abraham Wilkinson
who had known him eighteen months;
Ann Hind
, who had known him two years and an half;
David Davis
, between two and three years; Aaaron Lawton, a twelvemonth;
Anthony Free
, two or three years; and
John Pilkinton
, who all gave him a good character.)

To Larcher. What time did you see the prisoner in the Old Bailey, and the corner of Newgate-street? - I believe it was about seven o'clock when I first saw him; I parted with him about a quarter after.
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the First London Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

398.
JOHN GLOVER
was indicted for
that they together with five hundred other persons and more, did, unlawfully, riotously, and tumultuously assemble, on the 6th of June , to the disturbance of the publick peace, and did begin to demolish and pull down the dwelling-house of
Richard Akerman
, against the statute, &c.

WILLIAM SHEPPARD
sworn.

I am one of Mr. Akerman's servants. I was at the main gate of the prison on Tuesday night, the 6th of June, when Mr. Akerman's house and the jail were attacked. At about seven o'clock in the evening the mob assembled in a very riotous manner armed with different kinds of things, bludgeons and pickaxes. At about eight o'clock in the evening, I believe it was, I saw the prisoner or rather before eight o'clock, at the main gate of the prison; I saw him through the chequers of the gate; he was very busily employed with the rest. He was not the first person who came up with the pick-ax to the gate, but he assisted with a pick-ax; there is a main gate goes over the lattice; he was not the first person who began at that gate, but I saw him there afterwards.

Describe particularly what you saw him do? - He took one of the pick-axes out of one of the men's hands, who had been employed at it before, and tried at it himself; there were others afterwards employed in the same way, but after all they could not penetrate the gate so as to get in. Mr. Akerman's goods being thrown into the street, when they found they could not get in by the pickaxes, and other tools, which they had, they placed Mr. Akerman's things up against the gate and set fire to them. I saw the prisoner employed four or five times in piling up the things; we endeavoured to throw them down with broomsticks, and to quench the fire with water.
Was the gate actually set on fire? - Several times, it might as far as I know be nine or ten times attempted.
How far was the prisoner from you? - Not above a yard or a yard and a half from me.
How long had you an opportunity of observing his person? - I observed his person as near as I can recollect from between seven and eight o'clock till near ten.
Are you able to say that is or not the man or have you any doubt about it? - I have no doubt about it, for I saw him both by day-light and fire-light.
Cross Examination.
You are one of the turnkey's? - I am.
How long have you been in that employment? - I cannot say particularly, five or six months, under or over.
What was you before? - Turnkey at New Prison till my master died.
Where was you before that? - I belonged to Bedlam Hospital.
This man had a pick-ax? - Yes.
All the time you saw him? - I cannot say all the time, he and others tried to break the lattice of the left hand gate to break in.
You say he got a bromestick afterwards? - No, I got a broomstick; I believe he might have something else at first in his hand, but he took the pick-ax in his hand at the gate.
He was not above a yard from you? - I said not above a yard and an half from me.
You speak now of the time the prisoner was a yard and an half from you at the time the things were on fire at the door? - Yes.
Was not the fire between you and the prisoner? - No; he was between me and the fire when he came up on the steps.
He piled up the wood at the door of the prison to set it on fire? - Yes.
We heard of an iron bar some time ago? - They were armed with different kind of weapons.
Have not you said the prisoner had an iron bar? - I said a pick ax.
Have not you said at other places he had an iron bar? - No, I did not say so; there was something mentioned of a gun barrel before the magistrate.
You said so? - From my fellow servant saying so.
Did you say any thing before the magistrate of the pick-ax? - It was mentioned there.
I ask you if you mentioned it, did you Sheppard before the justice of peace say that this prisoner at the bar had a pick-ax in his hand? - Yes, I believe I did say so.
Did you mention a gun-barrel? - No.
I heard there was a gun-barrel at Mr. Akerman's door.
By who? - Mr. Lee I believe.
Have you been out of England? - I have been in Yorkshire; I have never been but at the Isle of White.
You have never been in a country where Blacks are the inhabitants? - No.

Then you are only accustomed to see Blacks by accident as I am, where was you when you saw the prisoner by day-light? - At the gate of the prison; I was at the gate from morning till night. I saw several Blacks and Tawnies on the 8th or 9th of June. I heard there were a number of persons taken up who were in the Poultry-Compter; I went to see if there were any who had escaped from Newgate. I saw the prisoner, I said to my fellow servant that is the man who set fire to our gate.
Did you speak to the prisoner then? - No.
I asked him afterwards whether he knew me? He said he did not.
Did not the prisoner say in your hearing he had a gun-barrel in his hand? - No, he did not; I might hear the latter part, but I do not think I did.

You cannot remember what passed two or three days ago, yet you are come to swear to the person of a Black you saw by candlelight? - He is not dressed now as he was then but I know his face perfectly well.
Court. Did you see more than one or two Blacks in the riot? - Yes; there were more than one.
When he was examined before the Lord Mayor you went to give evidence against him? - I did.
Did you tell the Lord Mayor every thing you remembered which you thought material? - Yes; to all the questions which were asked me.
Were you not asked to tell all you knew? - I do not know that; I did tell all I knew at that time.
Did not you know it was your duty to tell the magistrate all you knew upon the subject? - Certainly.
Why did not you tell all you knew? - I told all the questions that were put to me, as far as I knew.
Was not you asked about the prisoner and what you had see him do? - Certainly.
Did you tell the magistrate that the prisoner took a pick-ax out of another man's hand? - To the best of my knowledge I mentioned it.
Is it true what you have said, now did you see the man take the pick-ax out of another man's hand? - It is true.

WILLIAM LEE
sworn.

I am a servant of Mr. Akerman; I was in the hall at the great gate when the mob came, which was about seven o'clock, but the gate was not attacked at that time. When it was attacked I was at the debtors gate.

Did you see the prisoner in the course of that night? - Yes, but he was dressed in a rough short jacket, and had a round hat with dirty silver lace upon it. It was very near nine o'clock. When I saw him he was standing on the steps, thumping with somewhat, but I do not know what, against the gate, another man was chopping at it with a hatchet, which split it, and some pieces fell off. I was not half a yard from him at the time I was in the street; I suppose I staid five minutes at that time. I saw him at the Poultry Compter on the 8th or 9th of June, I believe. My master sent us to see if we knew any of the persons who were taken up. I saw the prisoner; I asked him how he came to behave in that manner with the iron bar? He said No it was not an iron bar, it was his master's gun-barrel. I am positive he is the man.
Cross Examination.
How many years have you been in this employment at Newgate? - About six years.
Was you ever out of this country? - Yes, I have been in Holland.
You was never any farther than that? - No.
You never saw this man above five minutes? - No.
You was but half a yard from him, and yet you could not discern what was in his hand? - No, there was such a mob, and I was a little terrified.
Is it very easy to know a Black? - I do not think he is a Black.
Did you ever see him before? - No.
Yet you could positively swear to him in the Compter? - Yes; I looked at him sometime in the Compter before I swore to him.
What time of day did you see him in the Compter? - In the forenoon.
The prisoner said very true that it was not an iron bar but a gun-barrel? - Yes.
You do not mean to make the jury believe that he said it was a gun-barrel he was thumping at the door with? - He said it was not an iron bar but his master's gun-barrel that he was there with.
You alter it every time, you said just now he said it was not an iron bar but his master's gun-barrel he was there with, now you leave out was there with? - I know he was there at the time.
Jury. Was the man in the Compter pointed out to you? - Not at all.
Did you see the prisoner any time in the day on Tuesday? - No not till eight o'clock.
Did not you say you saw him in the day? - I did not.

CHARLES BURKITT
sworn.

I am a servant of Mr. Akerman; when the prison was attacked I was inside the press-yard; I saw the prisoner at nine o'clock, as near as I can guess, upon the steps which lead to the felons gate, which is the main gate; I observed him have, as I thought, an iron bar in his hand, which was afterwards confessed to be a gun-barrel; I looked through the lattice of the gate; he attempted to poke it in my fac. They said, D - n you, open the gate and let the prisoners out or we will burn Newgate down. I saw him again, about half an hour after, in the same place; there was then same fire before the gate, and with the instrument he had in his hand he pushed the fire against the gate in order to burn it.

How many days was it after this before you saw him again? - I think it was on Thursday the 8th. I then saw him in the Compter; I saw him through the gate. I said, that is the man who burnt the gate down.

Did you see any other Black there? - This I call a copper coloured person; I saw a different kind of Black; I spoke to him; I said, Friend, you are not in the situation you was in upon the steps of Newgate with an iron bar in your hand. He said no, it was not an iron bar it was his master's gun barrel.

Who was present? -
Richard Hilliard
.
Cross Examination.
This is the same gate Sheppard was at? - Yes; Sheppard was backwards and forwards throwing water to cool the fire.
Sheppard was at the same gate you was and employed in the same way? - He was.
It was quite dark, only the light that came from the fire at this time? - It was not very dark at that time of night.
Was there not a vast glare of light? - Yes; between nine and ten o'clock the gate was opened by the desire of Mr. Alderman Wooldridge; then I was close to him; I had a perfect view of him.
When did you see him on Thursday? - Between ten and eleven o'clock.
Was Lee with you? - Yes.
Court. What did you say when Mr. Alderman wooldridge was there? - He stood close to the gate when I opened it; I had a perfect view of him.
You would not have known this was a gun-barrel if the prisoner had not told you so himself? - I imagined by the sound against the gate that it was an iron bar.
Had he it when you opened the gate to Alderman Wooldridge? - Yes.

RICHARD HILLIARD
sworn.

I am servant to Mr. West the keeper of the Poultry-Compter. We had a matter of a hundred prisoners brought in; Mr. Akerman's three servants came to see if they knew any of them; they went in; they pitched upon this Black before they had been there five minutes; some words arose between Burkitt and him about an iron bar; all the answer I heard the prisoner make was, it was not an iron bar but his master's gun barrel.
Cross Examination.
What time was the prisoner committed? - I do not know; if I had known I should have been called I would have brought my master's books.
- WEST sworn.
I am keeper of the Poultry Compter; it was on Friday the prisoner declared to his aster, in my hearing, that it was a gun-barrel; and that he took it out of his apartment.
Prisoner. I leave my defence to my counsel.
For the Prisoner.
- SAVILLE sworn.
I am a watch-maker, and live in a court on Snow-hill.

Did you make any observation on the mob on Tuesday night as they came this way? - I did; about seven o'clock on Tuesday evenning, I think it was the 6th of June, I had heard the mob were determined to destroy Newgate. I heard the mob coming in a very formidable manner. I came upon Snow-hill and stood upon the kirb-stone, within half a yard of some of the mob, as they passed by to the amount, I believe, of five hundred.
Whether you saw any Black in that mob? - I did; a very remarkable person; I should know him ten years hence if I saw him.
Was he very active? - Yes, he had something which seemed to be the spoke of a wheel.

Do you think the prisoner is the man? - I do not; a gentleman told me his black servant was taken up; he desired me to go and see if the man in the Compter was the man I saw. I went and saw him, and am very certain it was not the prisoner.

If there was any other Black in the mob is it not probable you must have seen him? - Many of the mob had passed before I came out; I did not see any other; I saw the Black afterwards, who passed me, upon the top of Mr. Akerman's house, very active.
Cross Examination.
Do you mean to say there was but one Black in the mob? - I saw but one.

Court. Did you go to Newgate? - I did, about a quarter after seven o'clock; then I saw the Black there whom I had seen before; he had a piece of linen shaking out of the window of the one-pair-of-stairs; I was opposite Mr. Akerman's house.
He had something which looked like the spoke of a coach wheel, you could not see at that distance that it was the spoke of a coach wheel? - To the best of my knowledge it was.

JAMES
M'MAHON sworn.
You are in the army? - I am.

Was you in the neighbourhood the night Newgate was destroyed by the mob? - I was on Snow-hill, within a few yards of St. Sepulchre's Church; as soon as the men with the pick-axes passed me, a Black came by me; he had a bludgeon in his hand, like the spoke of a coach wheel; he passed me smiling; he struck the ground with his stick and said, Now Newgate. As soon as I heard that a Black was taken I went into the Poultry-Compter to see if it was the same, but it was a different person.
They went directly to Newgate? - Yes.
Did you see any other Black? - No.
If there had been another do you think you could have distinguished him? - Very easily.
- PHILLIPS Esq. sworn.

The prisoner at the bar was my servant. He was ordered go to from my house in Westminster, to my chambers in Lincoln's-Inn to bring a drawer with some papers; he was ordered to bring every thing away but the heavy articles.
Was there any gun barrel? - Yes, with neither lock nor stock, it had been tried and had burst.
How long has the prisoner lived with you? - About twelve years; he was a quiet, sober, honest servant.
Had he any opportunities of being connected in any respect with these rioters, had he been out in the course of the day? - I believe, he had not indeed. I have trusted him with large sums of money.
It was in the evening he was sent for these things? - He left Westminster, I believe, about four o'clock in the evening to execute these orders.
This gun-barrel was in the chambers at the time? - Yes, I believe it was.
Cross Examination.
What time did he return? - He has never returned since.

GUILTY (
Death .)
Tried by the First London Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

399.
JAMES KINGSNOOTH
was indicted for
that he together with five hundred other persons and more, unlawfully, riotously, and tumultuously did assemble on the 6th of June , to the disturbance of the publick peace, and did begin to demolish and pull down the dwelling-house of
Richard Akerman
, against the form of the statute, &c.
(The counsel for the crown did not call any witnesses in support of this indictment.)
NOT GUILTY .

400.
RICHARD WILSON
was indicted for
stealing a wooden cask, value 12 d. and two gallons of raspberry brandy, value 8 s. the property of
Thomas Langdale
, June 7th .

STEPHEN BROOM
sworn.

I am a watch-maker. On Wednesday evening the 7th of June, at a little after seven o'clock, I was going towards Newgate-street; the mob were then destroying Mr. Langdale's house; I saw the prisoner come out of Mr. Langdale's with a two-gallon keg; he went towards Field-lane with it, and I saw no more of it.
Did you know him before? - Yes, he sells garden-stuff about the streets ; I have seen him several times; I am quite sure he is the man.

WILLIAM HOGGARD
sworn.

I know the prisoner; I saw him at the Golden Anchor at the corner of some street on Saffron-hill, on the Wednesday evening that Mr. Langdale's house was destroyed, at about seven o'clock; he had a keg of raspberry brandy on his shoulder. I was in the house drinking a pint of beer; he insisted on my coming out and drinking some of it; I drank about a quartern.
Did you ask him where it came from? - No.

JOHN SEABROOK
sworn.

On Wednesday the 7th of June, while I was sitting at the Golden Anchor door, Saffron-hill, the prisoner came by with a keg, what was in it I cannot tell, he dropped it out of his hand, and swore an oath and said Mr. Langdale owed him twenty pounds, and he was obliged to take that in part. He seemed very drunk; he dropped it at the door.
PRISONER's DEFENCE.

I have plenty of friends to my character. I never was in Mr. Langdale's house; I was coming along; there was a great mob at the house, they said, d - n your eyes, no Popery, no Popery, where is your cockade? I had no cockade in my hat; a man gave me this cask; I did not know what was in it.
For the Prisoner.

JOHN KAYSER
sworn.

I live in Turnmill-street. I sent for the prisoner about eight o'clock, or a little after, on the Wednesday night, to assist me, because the next house was threatened to be set on fire; he came without his coat and stockings, and staid all night till ten o'clock next morning.
Cross Examination.
He came without his shoes or stockings? - Without his stockings, he had been in bed.
Was he in liquor? - No.
(The prisoner called four other witnesses who gave him a good character.)

GUILTY .
Imp. 12 months .
Tried by the First London Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

401.
SOPHIA OWEN
was indicted for
stealing a pair of linen sheets, value 8 s. and a child's linen frock, value 2 s. the property of
William Tugwell
, June 30th .
- TUGWELL sworn.

I am the wife of
William Tugwell
; we lodge in Stone-cutter-street, Fleet-market
. Last Friday I went out to the next door for about five minutes; when I returned I met the prisoner on the steps with the things mentioned in the indictment in her apron. I stopped her, and asked her what she had got in her apron? she said her sister's clothes. I desired to look at them. I found my child's frock and a pair of linen sheets in her apron. I charged the constable with her.

(
William Wilson
, the constable, produced the sheets and frock, and they were deposed to by the prosecutrix.)
PRISONER's DEFENCE.
I was very much in liquor; I did not know the next morning what I was in custody for.

GUILTY .
Imprisoned 6 months .
Tried by the First London Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

402.
THOMAS LEWIS
was indicted for
that he, together with twenty other persons and more, did, unlawfully, riotously, and tumultuously, assemble, on the 2d of June , to the disturbance of the publick peace, and did begin to demolish and pull down the dwelling house of
Joseph Francis Lavana
, commonly called Count Haslang , against the form of the statute, &c.

(The counsel for the crown informed the court that they had but one witness whose testimoney could affect the prisoner, and that witness's credit having been impeached on a former trial, they would not produce him in support of this indictment.)
NOT GUILTY .

403.
ABRAHAM DAVIS
was indicted for
that he, together with thirty other persons and more, did, unlawfully, riotously, and tumultuously, assemble, on the 7th of June , to the disturbance of the public peace, and did begin to demolish and pull down the dwelling house of
George Beckett
, against the form of the statute, &c.

GEORGE BECKETT
sworn.

I am a cabinet-maker , in Crown-court, Grub-street
. My house was attacked, between four and five o'clock in the afternoon of Wednesday the 7th of June. I was in my garret. I heard a tumultuous noise; I ran down stairs; the first person I saw coming in at the door with that multitude was the prisoner at the bar; he had a bludgeon or stick in his hand, with which I saw him break the windows; he was the next person to me. I went out of the house and left him breaking the windows; and I saw no more of him. The mob demolished the furniture; they broke the closets and shelves down.
Did they break down the wainscoting? - The house has very little wainscoting in it; what there was they demolished.

Did you ever see the prisoner before? - No. I saw the prisoner again on Wednesday the 26th; I was coming home from Old-street; he was in White-Cross-street with a pea-cart; I immediately knew him again; he is so remarkable I could not mistake him; I am sure he is the man.
Did you mention that to any body before? - I mentioned it in my own family that one person struck me more than the rest.
PRISONER's DEFENCE.
The prosecutor swears I broke the windows I have but two fingers; I have persons to prove that I was at the Fleet prison from two till six o'clock.
For the Prisoner.

WILLIAM WILLIAMS
sworn.

I keep an eating house in Grub-street; my father employed the prisoner to bring his goods from the Fleet; my father is in the Fleet; he came home and desired me to get some body to help to move his goods, as the Fleet was threatened to be set on fire. I went up to White Cross-street and got a cart. The prisoner was asleep in the stable; I waked him; that was a little before two o'clock.
What stables were they; - I do not know the name of the stables; there is a box maker at the corner of the yard. I drove the cart and he rode within side to Fleet-lane; it is a little potatoe cart.

Was the cart his? - Whether it was his or his master's I do not know; he mounted the cart while I went into the Fleet and helped to bring the goods down; when we had loaded the cart and came from it, it was past six o'clock; I believe the mob were then breaking Mr. Langdale's windows, because as we came to the top of the market we saw two men on the leads.
How far is Grub-street from the Fleet? - About a quarter of a mile.
Was he with you all the time? - Yes; from before two till almost seven o'clock; then I unloaded the cart.
Was you acquainted with him before? - No; my father bespoke the cart, and I went a little before two for it.
Cross Examination.
What evening was this? - Wednesday evening; the same evening the Fleet was on fire.

PATRICK WILLIAMS
sworn.

I was a prisoner at the Fleet; on the Wednesday when this happened I was afraid of losing my little property; I ran to my children who were able to help me. I met my son William. I said come down and help me, as the Fleet is threatened to be set on fire; that was rather before twelve o'clock. I told him I had spoke to a man who keeps a little cart. I went back to pack up my things as fast as I could; about an hour or two after my two sons William and Thomas came; they helped to lead the things into the cart; I knew nothing of the prisoner before, only he was employed to carry my goods; he is a carman; he was employed from two o'clock. I did not get out of the Fleet till near six o'clock; I walked along by the cart all the way; the cart, I believe, belongs to one Armston; I know nothing of the prisoner; I spoke to Armston for the cart.

ANN ROWLAND
sworn.
I saw the prisoner bring the goods from Mr. Williams's house on Wednesday the 7th of this month between six and seven in the evening.
Counsel for the Crown. There is so much doubt in this case that I desire the prosecution may proceed no farther.
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the Second Middlesex Jury before Mr. Justice NARES.

404.
DAVID EVANS
was indicted for
that he, together with forty other persons and more, did, unlawfully, riotously, and tumultuously, assemble, on the 6th of June , to the disturbance of the public peace, and did begin to demolish and pull down the dwelling house of the Right Honourable
William Earl of Mansfield
, against the form of the statute, &c.

THOMAS PARKER
, Esq. sworn.

You are in the commission of the peace for the county of Middlesex? - I am. I went to Bloomsbury-square
about three o'clock in the morning; the mob was very violent. I read the riot act at about half after three; I saw the prisoner with people, some of whom had bottles and bowls of liquor, which I imagined they got from Lord Mansfield's house, endeavouring to make the soldiers drunk; the mob was very violent; in order to keep them off from the soldiers it was thought necessary to order the soldiers to charge their bayonets; the men were drawn up from the corner of the iron rails which surrounded the grass, to the Duke of Bedford's wall; the prisoner was then with other people near the watch-house; the mob were very troublesome, and endeavoured to force the lines, but they were repulsed by the soldiers. I then went up to the prisoner and spoke to him, knowing the livery; I saw he was in liquor; I desired him to go home, and told him I was very certain Sir
Thomas Sewell
would be very angry at a servant of his for appearing in such a riot. He attempted to break through the rank a second time after that, whether he succeeded or not I cannot say. It was not his way home to break through the ranks, because his way home was either by the Archbishop of York's house, or he might have gone down a little street which comes from Southampton-row, and King-street.

Could he have gone by the archbishop's house? - Yes, that was left open. After I had done that I went to the Secretary of State's office, and saw Mr. Frazier; I told Mr. Frazier I was very sorry that there were so many servants concerned in that riot, amongst which I mentioned that I had seen a servant of Sir Thomas Sewell's.
What was the part which the prisoner seemed to take? - He seemed to be animating the mob.

During the time you saw the prisoner there, what were the rest of the mob doing? - Behaving very violent, ballooing, crying No Popery! throwing stones and glass bottles. One of the privates of the guards was wounded exceedingly, and Mr. Lowton was wounded with a glass bottle; the mob were then pulling down Lord Mansfield's house and burning the furniture.
Cross Examination.
The prisoner was in liquor? - Yes.
He had no arms nor any weapon with him? - I did not see him have any.

Captain
BARNET
sworn.
I was detached to Bloomsbury-square about ten o'clock; I remained there till five in the morning.

Do you remember at any time in the course of that night or morning seeing the prisoner,
David Evans
? - I do; I first saw him at half past one.
Did you observe him doing or saying any thing? - Not doing any thing, but talking much with other servants. There was a servant with him who was extremely insolent to me, and was abusing the guard.
How long do you think you saw the prisoner there? - I saw him there from half past one till five.

Had you occasion to observe his conduct at any other time? - Not particularly till the morning, when he attempted to pass the guard, and was told by them that he could not pass that way, he remained some time in front of the guard, then he forced his way through. Mr. Parker told him He knew his master and desired him to go about his business. Colonel
Woodford
, who was commanding officer at that time, and came with a detachment to assist me, said if he did not go on immediately about his business, he would take him into custody. I did not see him afterwards.
Cross Examination.
It was another person who was so abusive? - Yes.

He was outside the guard the whole time? - He was continually passing and re-passing my guard during the whole time, and he once came up and spoke to the serjeant of the guard; I told him to go away from the guard.
- ESCOURT sworn.

I was at Lord Mansfield's at about two o'clock; and I was there at three o'clock, and from then till between five and six in the morning. I was there when Mr. Parker came with a party of guards. Mr. Parker appointed me a constable; I remained there till between five and six in the morning, when the whole business was over. After the soldiers had fired between five and six o'clock, I think it was past five, I was called to by some of the people as a peace officer; they said, Sir, here is a servant making a great riot, I wish you would come and speak to him. The prisoner was then near the rails which surround the square on that side of the line of soldiers which came from the Duke of Bedford's wall to the rails; I went and told him I knew him very well, and I knew his master Sir
Thomas Sewell
. I advised him to go home, or I must take him into custody. He recollected me; he made no answer nor did I stay there any longer; I turned about and never saw him after.
At what time was that? - After the soldiers had fired; it was about five o'clock, I believe.
Court. Had you observed him before the people told you there was a servant very troublesome? - No, I had not seen him.
Cross Examination.
Then he went home? - I do not know; I saw no more of him.
Prisoner. I leave my defence to my counsel.
For the Prisoner.
Mr. CRAGGS sworn.

I am an officer belonging to the Master of the Rolls. The prisoner has lived servant with Sir
Thomas Sewell
ever since December. He came from Mr. Clare; I enquired his character of Mr. Clare; he gave him such a character as induced the Master of the Rolls to take him. He lived with Sir Thomas till he was taken up. I never heard any other than his behaving very decently and properly from every thing I have heard from Lady Sewell and the family; he is a decent, orderly servant.
Do you know that he went to see a lady from the house that night? - I do not live in the family; I have heard so.
Mr. CLARE sworn.

The prisoner lived with me twelve months; he was very diligent in his business; he kept very much at home. He was a sober orderly man, and a good servant; I had a very good character of him from his last place; they parted with him because they were going to live in the country. I did not give him warning, he gave me warning and left me to go to a better place.

Mr. Parker. Lady Sewell had such an opinion of him, as Captain
Sibthorpe
informed me, that she put great confidence in him; Captain
Siothorpe
gave that account, he is now in the country.
Mr. MAY sworn.
I have known him four or five years; he is a sober, honest, peaceable man; he lived servant with a relation of mine two years and an half, who always spoke exceeding handsome of him.
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the Second Middlesex Jury before Mr. Justice NARES.

405.
GEORGE SIMPSON
was indicted for
that he did unlawfully, maliciously, wilfully, and feloniously set fire to the dwelling-house of
Victor Amada de la Tour
, commonly called Marquis de Cordon
.
2d Count. For setting fire to an out-house.
3d Count. For setting fire to the house generally, June 2d .

JOHN ROGERS
sworn.

I am a brick-maker, and live in Coffin-court. I came by the Sardinian ambassador's house between eleven and twelve o'clock. The chapel is in Duke-street
, the house is in Lincoln's-Inn-fields. I heard a noise in Duke-street; coming along I saw a fire in the street. I came and stood at the east end of the chapel to look, as other spectators did; I saw several people and the prisoner bringing out books, benches, and the lining of the chapel, and other things, and throwing them upon the fire.
Did you know the prisoner before? - I never saw him to my knowledge before that night.

Are you sure it is he? - Yes. I stood by some stables facing the chapel door; the prisoner came up to me, laid hold of me by the collar, and said, D - n your eyes, or blast your eyes, where are your colours!

What did he mean by your colours? - My not having a cockade in my hat I suppose. I told him I had seen Lord Mountmorres in trouble in Parliament-street, that I offered him my cockade, and his lordship desired me to give it to his coachman, as somebody else had given him one, which I accordingly did; I threw the prisoner over my leg and threw him down; I begged his pardon; then he left me and went to the fire; he took up five pieces of board, about the length of my arm, which were on fire, and set them against the right-hand door-post going into the eastern door, immediately after that the door-post was on fire. It was then reported that the military were coming.

Court. You do not know for certain that the fire was occasioned by the boards he set there? - It was not on fire before he set the boards there, but I saw the post burning afterwards. When it was reported that the military were coming, the people who were spectators absconded, and I absconded myself.
How long do you think you was there? - I had not my watch. I am sure I was not there a quarter of an hour.
How soon after was the prisoner taken? - I do not know; he was in custody soon after before the Lord-mayor for a misdemeanour, and was discharged.

Are you able to say from your observation of his person that he is the man? - Yes, he had a cut in his coat; he has not the same coat on now. I wrote a letter to Lord Hilisborough when things were settled and they began to take up people, describing the prisoner. I took him to be a shoemaker or blacksmith, by the long apron he had on. I sent the letter about the 11th or 12th day of the month.
Was you the first who gave information of him? - I cannot say, I told the constable if he saw such a person to take him.
Was it on your information he was taken up? - I believe it was; I got a party of soldiers, and he was taken to the London Hospital.
Did you know of any reward at that time? - No, I did not know of it till I heard it mentioned by Mr. Chetham here. I wrote to Lord Hillsborough that I wanted no see or reward.
Do you claim the reward? - No, I never shall; I do not want the reward.
Cross Examination.
What business are you? - A brick maker.
Do you follow that business? - Yes, on my stock; I have not made any this year; I made five thousand last year.
You was going accidentally by, and stood at the stable opposite? - Yes.
There was I suppose a great quantity of people? - No great quantity of people, there were several there.
You never saw the prisoner before? - I never say him before excepting twice. When he was taken up for setting fire to this place, I happened to be mentioning it to this constable.
Did you see a great number of boys and lads there? - Yes, and some men.

How came you to observe this man in particular? - I should not have taken notice of him if he had not come up and taken me by the collar. I took notice when I threw him over my legs that he had bandy legs.
He was taken up for some offence? - By Mr. Langdale's clerk I believe, but I did not know he was taken up.

How long was it before you charged him with this after you had found out the man? - I had information from the master he served his time with, where he was. When I found where he was I went to Mr. Alderman Wilkes; I got a party of soldiers and took him.

Court. How came you to find him out? - I was in a publick-house describing him, particularly to a constable, his size, his clothes and his legs, if he met with such a man to secure him, and send to me, and I would appear against him, for his impudence in collaring me. There were two persons sitting in a box, one said, that is our George. I did not take any notice only hearing him say it is our George, till the Monday following, then I happened to be in the house again about the hour of four o'clock, drinking a pint of porter; his master who was in the house on the Thursday before, happened to come in; he said he never heard a man describe another so near in his life as I described his servant. I asked him if he knew the man? He said yes, he served part of his time with him. I asked him where he was? He said there was no occasion to enquire, for he was far enough from here now, for he had been in prison and been discharged, and was far enough off by this time. With that I asked him if he had worked for him lately? He said no, the last place he worked at was for a widow in Shoe-lane, who was now married again. I enquired there for the prisoner, describing his person; she said his name was
George Simpson
, but he had been in prison, and was discharged, and she and her husband were not willing to discover where he was to be found. The next morning as her husband and I were going together to Mr. Alderman Wilkes, we happened to meet Mr. Wilkes in the street; I told Mr.
Wilkes
the whole affair; he granted me a warrant, and I got a guard of soldiers and took him up.
Jury. Was it not dark when you saw the prisoner first? - It could not be dark when there was a fire for the length of this sessions house.
He had a long apron on? - Yes.
How do you know he had crooked legs? - By throwing him down over my leg.

JOHN GOODRIDGE
sworn.

I am a carpenter, in Shoe-lane; the prisoner lodged with me three months; on Friday night the 2d of June he left my house about nine in the evening and was not at home again till the next morning; I saw him the next morning between eight and nine o'clock. I asked him, George, where have you been all night? He said, Master I have been to the fire. I said George, you had better been at your work, or sitting for your work, and not lie out of my house. I asked what fire? He said, at the Danish ambassador's; he said, D - n my eyes, master, we have burnt it down, we have had fine fun! and then he said he would go home to bed; he said, if you live two or three days longer you will see half London on fire. He went home and went to bed; he lay till two or three o'clock in the afternoon; he got up again, and did a little work till about seven; he said he was so ill he could not do any more that night, but if I chose he would do a little in the morning to make his work up, which he did; he had some roll and tea for breakfast and went to bed on Sunday all day; on the Sunday night he came out about eight or nine o'clock; he said he would go out and get him something to drink and go to bed, which he did.
Cross Examination.
What are you? - A carpenter.
What is he? - A shoe-maker.
He worked for you? - Yes; I carried on both businesses.
This conversation happened on the 3d? - Yes.
Did not this strike you as a very wicked thing? - It did very much.
Did not you go to an alderman directly? - No, because it was only his words; I did not then, I did afterwards.
Then you went and gave him a good character? - No, we were afraid he had been concerned in oivers robberies.
When he was taken up why did not you tell the alderman this? - I thou ght it did not signify as it was only his words.
Can you read? - Yes.
You heard there was a reward before he was taken up? - No.
Did not you read it? - No.
The first time he was taken up he was discharged? - Yes; he was taken up for picking a gentleman's pocket; they asked if I was his master? I said yes.
Did he keep good hours? - No; and because I was his master he was discharged; that was all I was asked.
You live in Shoe-lane? - Yes.
How long have you lived there? - A twelvemonth.
He lay at your house? - Only one night after this.
How came you not to get rid of him? - At this time I was afraid of apprehending him.
Are you and your man upon an equal footing? - No.
He came and told you he had done this, and meant to burn down half London? - Yes; he told me this publickly in the street, but a few yards from the door.
Who heard this besides yourself? - I do not know that there was any body nigh me.
Perhaps he mentioned it to others as well as you? - Not that I know.
Who did you mention it to? - Mr. Wilkes.
Did you not tell it before? - No; I did not know any consequence could arise from his words.
You do not know that what a man says is evidence against himself? - No.
How came you to be a witness if you had not told it to any body? - I was sent for by means of Rogers coming to see for him.
Then you told him this? - No, I did not.
How came it into your mind to tell it at last? - When was before Mr. Wilkes he told me to tell all I knew of him, and then I told it.
You never read this proclamation which was pasted at the corner of every street? - I did not.

JOHN BATES
sworn.
I am a carpenter.
Do you know the situation of the Sardinian ambassador's chapel and house? - Yes.
Is the Chapel joining to the house? - Yes, it is on the north side.

Is there a communication between the house and the chapel? - There is on the south side a covered passage, which leads from the south side of the house, from the one-pair-of-stairs; underneath that is a place for bottles, for the use of the butler; and there was a door into the chapel below stairs from the butler's closet, which is now closed up; there is also a communication on the north side which goes into the sacristary for the servants and other people to go into the chapel.
Does the chapel appear to be of equal date with the house? - The Chapel was built in the year 1763; it had been burnt down.
Is the chapel now burnt down entirely? - The north side of it is injured by the fire; the galleries are injured, and I believe six pillars were burnt and a part of the floor.
Cross Examination.
You are a carpenter? - Yes.
This chapel is a distinct building from the house? - There is a communication with the house.
As one house communicates with another? - There in an immediate communication with the vestry, which is a part of the house.
There is an eight foot passage between the house and the chapel on the south side? - Yes.
Then there is eight feet distance, I understand, between the house and the chapel? - There is; a projecting wing; I have made a sketch of it, if it will be any information to you (producing it).
Court. There are, I see, three communications; one up stairs from the ambassador's apartment to the chapel, one which has been stopped up, for the use of the servants, and one to the sacristary.
The chapel was built since the house?
Bates. In the year 1763, when the chapel was built, these communications, I under stand, were made, which were not before.
It might be separated from the house without injuring the house at all? - Yes.
Take away the chapel and make windows of the doors, and the house will be complete? - Yes, they were windows before; they are taken out and reversed and put on the south side.
As a builder do you suppose this chapel a dwelling house or a building adjoining to a house? - I look upon it as a building adjoining to a house.

LEONARD LOBAS
sworn.
I am servant to the ambassador.

What is the ambassador's name? -
Victor Amida
, Marquis de Cordon de la Tour.
Was the Marquis in possession of this dwelling-house on the 2d of June? - Yes.

What is the ambassador's family name? -
Victor Amida
, Count de la Tour, Marquis de Cordon, his father is called Count de la Tour.
PRISONER's DEFENCE.
This Mr. Rogers says he never saw me before; he lives up the court next door to where I work; he used to bring jobs to me and stay while I did them.
To Rogers. The prisoner says he lives next door to you? - Yes.
Did you know he worked there? - No,
I never was in the house three times in my life; when I sent shoes to mend I always sent my children; I never saw him in the shop, to my knowledge, in my life.
For the Prisoner.

Mr.
THOMAS THORPE
sworn.
I keep the Globe-tavern in Fleet-street.
Do you know Rogers who has been examined as a witness? - About three months ago John Rogers applied to me to sign a paper in order to recover some money at the Assurance-office.
Give us an account of what is his general character? - The report was that he wilfully set his house on fire.
What is his general character? - He is a man of a very bad character.
Do you know any thing of the other man? - No.
Cross Examination.
Have you ever heard any thing against his character but what alludes to this transaction? - In our neighbourhood his character is very bad.
Has it arisen from this transaction - Yes.
Mr. JELLICO sworn.
I am an upholsterer in Fleet-street.
Have you known that man Rogers? - I never saw him in my life.
What is his character? - I know nothing of his character further than concerning a fire.
Do you know the other witness Goodridge? - I do not.
Mr. FENNING sworn.
I am first clerk in the Royal Assurance-office.
Do you know any thing of Rogers? - Only officially; we enquired his character in consequence of a fire.
Counsel for the crown. This certainly is not evidence.
Cross Examination.
Do you know any thing of him? - Only from this transaction; he is a very bad man and ought not to be believed.
Court. So far as your knowledge goes he is a man of bad character? - Yes. It is intended to prosecute him for perjury.
Why do not they do it? - The information is very recent.
- BRISCOE sworn.
I am a printer.
Do you know Goodridge? - I have seen him; he lives along with Mrs. Tiller; I do not know whether he is married to her.
Do you know any thing of his character? - I do not know any thing particular of his character; his character is very indifferent in the neighbourhood.
Do you know the prisoner? - He has been in my shop; I do not know much of him.
Cross Examination.
Is his bad character owing to his living with a woman of a different name? - I cannot say; I do not say it was from that.

WILLIAM FARDING
sworn.

I have known Simpson upwards of five years; he lived with me; I had a very good character with him; I believe him to be a very honest lad; I have trusted him to receive money for me, and I never missed a farthing.
What are you? - I keep the Golden Horse, Aldersgate-street; he has left me three years.
Have you known him since? - Yes, he has always kept to work and never been beholden to any body I believe.

RICHARD KENDRICK
sworn.
I am a plumber. I have known the prisoner four years; I never heard any thing against his character. I lodged in the same house. I never saw him in liquor, nor never heard any harm of him.
- READ sworn.

I am a shoe-maker, I have known
Simpson
these ten years; I never heard any thing amiss of him; he served me five years; he is a very honest lad; I never knew any thing to the contrary.
Cross Examination.
How long has he left you? - Five years.
Have you seen him frequently since? - Yes.
Have you had any reason to alter your opinion of him? - No.

RICHARD BENSON
sworn.

I have known the prisoner from a child; he has a very honest general character; he was under my care eight years; I was guardian to him. He was apprentice to Mr. Read; I never heard any thing dishonest of him.

JOHN JOHNSON
sworn.
I am a watch-maker. I have known him near fourteen years; he is strictly honest, and as to disposition, I believe, he is quite free from any thing of riot.
Cross Examination.
Do you live with him now? - No; I did eight or nine years ago; I have seen him frequently.

JOSEPH BRADDS
sworn.
I am a peruke-maker. I have known him upwards of two years; I never heard any thing dishonest of him in my life.

JAMES FARMER
sworn.
I have known him upwards of twenty years; I lived in the same house with him eight or nine years; I never heard any thing against his character till this time.
Cross Examination.
How long is it since you lived in the house with him? - I believe about twelve or thirteen years; I have seen him frequently since; I never heard any thing against him.

WILLIAM TUKE
sworn.
I am a distiller. I have known him ever since he was born; I never heard an ill word of him in my life before this time.
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the Second Middlesex Jury before Mr. Justice ASHHURST.

406.
RICHARD EVANS
was indicted for
stealing sixteen pounds weight of brass, value 5 s. the property of
John Reynolds
, June the 26th .

THOMAS BIRD
sworn.

On Monday the 26th of June I had been into Fore-street upon some business, between four and five o'clock; I went into the King's Head opposite Cripplegate Church; the prisoner and another man came in and called for a pot of beer; they sat down and drank. I observed the prisoner had something under his coat, which he frequently attempted to secrete; when he took out his money to pay for his beer I observed he had a large brass cock under his coat, what they call a stop cock. I suspected he had stolen the cock. I asked him what he was? He said he was a labourer. I asked him where he worked? Then he said he worked with Mr. Beardmore, did I know him? I said Beardmore and Reynolds in Barbican I knew very well. I went up to the landlord and told him my suspicion of the prisoner; then I went to Messrs. Reynolds and Beardmore and brought their clerk, Mr. Wilkins, with me to the publick-house. I showed him the prisoner and said that is the man. He said Richard, what is the reason you have not been at work? The prisoner said he had got too much liquor. Mr. Wilkins asked me if I was sure the prisoner had got the cock? I said he had. I went up to him and said, Friend, you have got a cock under your apron unless you have given it to the other person. The prisoner immediately took it from under his apron and laid it on the table. Mr. Wilkins asked him where he got that? He told him had it from the shop. He asked him what business he had with it? He said he had no particular business with it; he had taken it from the shop, and they might do what they would with him for they could not hang him.

Was he drunk or sober at that time? - He might have drank some liquor, but he was far from drunk at the time. Mr. Wilkins went and got a constable, and I stood with the prisoner while he was gone; some thing in his right hand coat pocket struck against the legs of a corporal in the militia. He said he had something else, and took it out of his pocket; it was a piece of metal; when that was taken out of his pocket I told the constable I thought it was his duty to search him; he was searched and we found another stop cock in his left hand pocket; then the constable said he thought it was necessary to send for his master, which we did. Mr. Reynolds came and talked to him about it; the prisoner again said, he had taken them; he might do what he would, he could not hang him.
- EDWARDS sworn.
I am a constable; the prisoner was stopped. I found a large cock on the table; the other cock and this piece of metal I took from him. (They were produced in court and deposed to by the prosecutor).
Reynolds. A piece of metal was found upon him which was broke off another piece which fitted exactly.
PRISONER's DEFENCE.
I tossed up with one of the men on Monday and got a little intoxicated; I have no witnesses.

GUILTY .
W .
Tried by the Second London Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

407.
THOMAS DOWNS
was indicted for
that he together with forty other persons and more, did unlawfully, riotously, and tumultuously assemble, on the 7th of June , to the disturbance of the publick peace, and did begin to demolish and pull down the dwelling-house of
John Lebarty
, against the form of the statute, &c.

ELIZABETH FRAZER
sworn.

How old are you? - Going of fifteen. I am servant to Mr. Lebarty, in St. Catherine's-lane
. I was a-bed in the house when the mob came; there was only my mother and me and another fellow servant in the house. I went to bed about eleven o'clock and went to sleep; my mother waked me. I got up and did not know which way to get down stairs the mob came up so fast; my room is adjoining to my master's; I was getting up at the head of the bed to get my petticoat and tumbled into my master's dining room where I saw the prisoner; I was very much terrified; I knew the prisoner a long time before; I went down stairs as soon as I could; the prisoner is one of Mr. Clark's runners; he was in the house that night and had change for half a guinea.
What were the mob doing at that time? - They broke the stairs below; they made their way up stairs as soon as they could.

What was the other part of the mob doing to the house? - They broke all the window frames and the brick wall down, and then they threw out the furniture, some of it was carried to the fire on Tower Hill, and some people carried some home to their own habitations; I did not go to see the fire.
Cross Examination.
When did you first charge this man? - My mother first charged him, and Mr. Sherwood's runners took him.
Do you recollect when he was taken? - No.
You and your mother told this immediately, I suppose? - Yes.
He was taken up immediately, I suppose? - No, he was not; he was before the justice about a week after.
When you got up, when the mob came in, you were very much frightened? - Yes.
Why did not you go the next day to the justice? - We went to Benjamin, the constable, he was afraid to take him up; my mother did not know there was to be any law then.
Did you go to the justices more than once? - No.
You did not charge him then, did you? - Yes; we said we knew him.
Then you was not there once when you run away? - No, I did not run away.
Do you know a constable of the name of Whitway? - No.
Do you know the other constable you told it to, I do not mean Benjamin? - I do not know a constable of that name; I told it to no constable but Benjamin.
Did not you go in company with Lebarty, your mother, Mr. Whitway, and the prisoner? - Yes; I went with a man, I did not know his name was Whitway.
At the time you went with him, Lebarty, your mother, and the prisoner, did not you at that time run away and would not make a charge against the prisoner? - No.

Did not your mother and all of you refuse to make a charge against the man? - Yes; my mother did, because she wanted to speak to her master; Mr. Sherwood's runners said my master was coming, and he was not come; the two runners of Mr. Sherwood well knew where my mother lived, because they had some apprehension my mother knew something against the prisoner; my mother went with Mr. Sherwood's runners the first time they came about it.

Court. Then you went away without giving a charge? - Mr. Sherwood's runners ordered us over the way till my master should come to us; we waited there from six till seven, and my master never came; my mother and I went both over the way, the justice said he did not want to hear what I had to say, but he heard my mother.
When your master did not come you went over the way to the justice's without him? - Yes; the next day I was examined at the Rotation-office in Whitechapel.
Where was this? - I cannot tell, I was a stranger; I did not know the place.
To what justice was it you went, if it was not to Whitechapel, and where did he live? - I do not know the justice we went to then, but the next day I was examined at Whitechapel Rotation-office.
Don't you know where it was? - No.

Counsel. I mean a week before this when you went with Whitway to the Rotation-office, and you and your mother went away and the justice discharged him? - I went with two of Mr. Sherwood's runners; I do not know where to.
You know Mr. Sherwood very well? - Yes.

Counsel for the crown. How soon after your master's house was demolished did you first see your master? - I did not see him at all for four or five days after his house was destroyed; I did not know where he lodged or where he was; my mother and I went the next day to find him out, but we could not.
Where did you first tell this story? - In Whitechapel, at the Rotation-office.
When was the prisoner taken up? - I do not know.
To whom did you first give any evidence against the prisoner? - First I went to Mr. Benjamin, then to the Rotation-office in Whitechapel, where Justice Sherwood examined me.
Was that the first time you was examined? - Yes.

MARY FRAZER
sworn.

I am the mother of the last witness. I lay at Mr. Lebarty's the night the mob came. I came about ten and went to bed about eleven o'clock; I went to sleep; when the mob came I jumped out of bed and opened the fore window; no sooner had I opened the window but there was a boy at the window; we had put lights in the window. I said I would open the door if they would not break it; before I could get to the top of the stairs the mob were up stairs; we lay in the back room; the mob thrust us into Mr. Lebarty's bed chamber; some boys opened the door of the fore room up one pair of stairs and the prisoner took a gun from the boy, and swore he would blow my heart out unless I would tell him where my master's money and papers were! after that another boy brought a sword or cutlass out of the same closet; the prisoner took that and pulled it out of the sheath; he held it over my head and said, he would split me in two if I did not tell him where my master's money and papers were. I said, gentlemen, don't do any mischief and cause murder, if you will go down stairs with me I will show you; the prisoner said I must stay a little till they had done their business there and then they would go down with me; we staid till they had destroyed what was in that room and thrown the furniture out of the window; I saw the prisoner beat out the frame of the window and throw the bed out I had laid on. He said D - n you, you old Papist bitch! come down stairs and show us where the money is; he several times called me a Popish bitch! I went down stairs; he followed me; I showed him the bar where Mr. Lebarty kept his liquor and money; I saw the prisoner go into the bar, and I came out immediately; that was the first opportunity I had of getting out of the house, and I saw no more of the prisoner; the back part of Mr. Lebarty's house was broke; whether he went that way or not I do not know; I saw him in the street by himself on the Sunday following in the forenoon. I knew him directly, because the chief thing I did in the room was to observe him. On the Sunday afternoon my daughter and I were in the house of one Mrs. Roberts, in East Smithfield; the prisoner then passed the door; I immediately told Mrs. Roberts that was the man who used me ill at Lebarty's; she said he is one of Justice Clarke's runners, and his name is
Thomas Downs
.

What did your daughter say upon that? - I believe she was in the yard playing with Mrs. Roberts's boy. That was not far from where I lodged. I went home and set down his name. On Monday I went to seek for Mr. Lebarty, and left word that I had seen one of the people who had been concerned in pulling down Mr. Lebarty's house, and had got his name; I went to one Mr. Brumett, a milk-man, in St. Catherine's, where I thought I might hear of Lebarty, and to a Jew officer, at the top of St. Catherine's-lane; I believe his name is Benjamin. As I was returning home, I met the beadle of Aldgate parish, and told him of it; he said why did I not go and make an information at the justice's. I went to the justice's; there was a guard of soldiers; I attempted to go in; they would not let me; that was on the Monday forenoon after the house was destroyed. My daughter was with me, there was a guard of soldiers brought from the Victualling office to Justice Clarke's in East Smithfield, to take a parcel of prisoners. I did not find Mr. Lebarty, till the Wednesday following.

When did you give the first information against the prisoner? - On the Wednesday at the Rotation-office in Whitechapel, which is almost opposite the church, I went with Lebarty; the Jew constable and the prisoner were there; as soon as I saw him, I said that is the man I saw in Lebarty's house, who pulled down the window. Lebarty, I, and my daughter went to the Rotation-office together.
Was your daughter with you when you endeavoured to get admitted to Justice Clarke's office? - She was.
Do you know any thing more? - I was sitting at the Fountain in the Minories; two of Justice Sherwood's runners came in a great hurry, and said Justice Sherwood had sent them for me.

When was that? - Some time after, I believe it was a week after; they said Lebarty was there waiting for me; my daughter was with me then. When I went there Lebarty was not there; I said I would not stay any longer, and then I was made a prisoner of, and was detained from my washing, in the publick-house, by these runners; I was kept till ten at night; then the justice examined me, and I swore to the prisoner.
Was your daughter examined then? - She was.
How long did your examination last? - Not a great while.
How long did your daughter's last? - Not long; we were only sworn that he was the person. I am certain and sure that he is the person.
Cross Examination.
You did not know him before but by sight? - Only by sight, my daughter knew him for many years.

Why did you enquire of any body else if you daughter knew him? - My daughter was not in the room when he used me ill with the gun and sword. She said she saw one of Justice Clarke's runners there, but then I did not know his name.
You knew Justice Clarke and Justice Sherwood too? - No, I did not.
You have been before them both before now? - No, I have been before Mr. Clarke, not Mr. Sherwood.
Your daughter has known this man's name for these two years? - Yes, I believe she did.
Why did not you apply to her? - She was not present when I saw him and he presented the gun and sword to me.
Did not you go to Mr. Clarke's to complain? - Yes, but was not admitted into the office. I did not go before Monday.
From the Wednesday to the Sunday, you never went to enquire after him? - I was not able to hold up my head hardly, I was so ill used in Mr. Lebarty's house.
How came you to recollect so readily that your daughter was at play at the moment the prisoner went by when you was at Roberts's? - I am not sure she was at play, I was stagnated at the sight of him.
If your daughter knew him before why did not you call her? - I was too stagnated at seeing him. I was at the Rotation-office, I believe it was on the Wednesday, and on the Thursday se'nnight.
Was your daughter there? - Yes.

Do not you recollect your daughter and you going away, and you would not give evidence? - No; I was there but I did not give evidence nor my daughter, because Mr. Lebarty did not choose to have any thing to do with the matter.
She knew the reason I suppose as well as you? - It was not the reason because I would not give evidence, but because Mr. Lebarty would have nothing to do with it.
So you and your daughter went away without giving any evidence? - We saw the prisoner, and said he was the person.
When you saw the prisoner there you made no charge against him nor your daughter? - No.
He was discharged? - No, he was not in custody, he was doing his duty, he had prisoners in charge I believe.
How soon after this was it that you chose to give evidence against him, it was a week after was it not? - I cannot tell, the justice's runners came to fetch me, it was some time after.
That was the 22d I believe? - I do not know, I saw no more of him till I was sent for.
If this man was so well known to your daughter, and the name told you by Roberts, how came you to go and get a pen and ink to write it down? - That I might not forget it.
But Roberts said he was one of Mr. Clarke's runners, and your daughter said the same, and she knew the name? - She knew him, I do not know that she knew his name.
You knew Justice Clarke's office, and Justice Sherwood's office, and all their runners very well I dare say? - No, I do not; I have been at Justice Clarke's office.
Have you all your warrants at Justice Clarke's office? - I never had a warrant in my life.
When you was so industrious to tell this in St. Catherine's-lane, why did not you go to the justice's? - I did not know the nature of law, I could not get in at the justice's.

When the runners came for you you say you was in prison, what was that for? - They said they would keep me till they went and took
Thomas Downs
.
Was you locked up? - No, I was in the room, they would not let me go out.
And your daughter too? - Yes.
Was not that because you had run away before? - No, I never ran away before.
Do you know Whitway? - No, I do not know him by name.
Court. Where was your daughter from the Wednesday the house was destroyed to the Sunday? - In lodgings with me all the time.

I suppose you naturally had a good deal of talk respecting that terrible night? - At that time I was too ill to be talked to. I was greatly hurt in Mr. Lebarty's house; I did not talk about the rioters all that time that I know of. My nose began bleeding from that time to Sunday; then it stopped bleeding, and I went out to Mrs. Roberts's.

Was you speechless all that time that you spoke nothing about it? - No, but my nose kept bleeding; I had a blow on the back of my head; we might speak that there were such riots, but not to any purpose.
When did she tell you she saw one of justice Clarke's runners there? - On the Friday she told me she saw some runners, some butchers, and Jews, in Mr. Lebarty's house.
Though she told you on Friday she knew one of Justice Clarke's runners was there, you never once asked her if she knew his name? - No.
