You only saw him as he passed by you, and you was very much frightened? - I saw him before at Mr. Lynch's, that night at about twelve o'clock. A gentleman desired me to give them a gallon of beer for them not to burn the goods there. I knew him again when he came into my house.
Might not you be mistaken in the person, when you say you saw him come up the second person? - I was with him in all the rooms of the house; I am sure he is the person.
Did you first inform against him? - I did not know it till I was sent for.
Are you sure the three persons at the bar are the persons of whom you have been speaking? - I am sure.

CHARLES LEE
sworn.
I lodged at Mr. Bradbury's, in Golden-lane; I was there at the time the mob came. I took particular notice of two persons.

Which two? - Those two (pointing to Price and Burn.)
Thompson
I know nothing of. I saw the mob come to Mr. Lynch's, the next door but one; I heard some of them, but I do not know which, say, the next shall be Mr. Bradbury's. I went to Mr. Bradbury's and said, for God's sake! remove what goods you can. I got some acquaintances to help me away with my goods; they had done at about a half after one, then they came to Mr. Bradbury's house; I begged and prayed of them, when they came to Mr. Bradbury's house, and I hung out a blue ribband and told them there was 10 Popery. I brought down a large church-bible I had; I went into the street and held it up and said, This is my religion; here is no Popery; for God's sake do not pull the house down; they made a ring and swore me to my religion; there were pails and barrels full of beer in the street, and they drank very freely; then they went into the house and had liquor at the bar; then a tall lamp-lighter went upon the stairs and said, Blast you, come along, and let us go up stairs and see what is there; the mob followed him. I went up stairs, I suppose I was the third who went up; when they came up the first pair of stairs they saw the bed-steads, the beds were removed. They said Blast their eyes, there is Popery here, else they would not have moved; then they began to break the windows; then they went from the one-pair-of-stairs into the two-pair-of stairs to my room; when they were in my room there was only a case of a chest of drawers left; they went to stamp out the partitions of the case of the chest of drawers; and then they broke the windows and part of the window frames. Price and Burn were into my room and in every room of the house assisting in doing the mischief. I stopped their hands several times and said, they did not know the consequence; they had bludgeons in their hands; there was a door between Mr. Bradbury's lodging room and mine, they burst that open and broke down part of the partition; they they proceeded into the garret; the tall lamp-lighter began breaking the windows in the garret, and then looked out at the window, pulled off his hat, and huzza'd, No Popery! There was a box locked, they broke it open; there was a fiddle in it; there were eight hands, I suppose, in the box at a time. Bradbury took up the fiddle and music books; they broke the garret windows. Then they came down into the club-room, and broke the chairs, and threw the things out of the windows into the street.
Are you positive to Price and Burn being there? - Yes; they were in the house from the top to the bottom of it. I went away with my wife and children.
Cross Examination.
You saw the first who went into the house? - No; the first who was on the stairs; I cannot tell who went first into the house.

Where was Mr. Bradbury when they came into the house? - I do not know; the second time I saw Price was about three or four days after in Clerkenwell Bridewell; they took me to see if I knew him; I described the colour of his coat and his hair, before I saw him.
Can you recollect how often you saw him? - Why should I recollect that; can that counsellor prove that he was not there, then I have done. My lord have you done with me?
Court. Not while the prisoner's counsel has any questions to ask you; you must answer that gentleman.
Counsel. How long after was it you saw Price in Clerkenwell? - I do not know, it might be two or three days.

ROBERT REMINGTON
sworn.

I was at Bradbury's at the time the mob were there. I knew Burn and Thompson; they were in Bradbury's house; I saw them go up stairs and throw the chairs out at the window; Burn pulled off his hat and balloo'd No Popery! the chairs were taken and broken to pieces.

Did you see Thompson do any thing; - He was in the house but I did not see him do any thing; they made Bradbury show his books; after the things were destroyed at Lynch's house they went back again; that was about half after one, and began to throw the furniture out; they left the house at near two o'clock. Thompson went up one-pair-of-stairs, and then to the two-pair-of-stairs.
Was he there as one of the mob, or as a spectator? - I did not see him do any thing, he was talking about religion on the outside of the door.
Cross Examination.
Was you there all the time the mob was in Bradbury's house? - Yes, I stood opposite.
Did you know Price? - Yes.
You did not see him there? - No.
If he had been there must you not have seen him? - Yes.
Do you know where Bradbury was when they first went into the house? - I believe in the house.
Do you know where Burn was when the mob rushed into the house? - I went into the house with the mob myself and saw Burn go into the house.
How many were gone in before Burn? - A great many; there was a great mob round the door.
If Price had gone in at the same time you must have seen him? - Yes.
Price lives in that neighbourhood? - I believe he does; his father lives in Golden-lane, and keeps hogs.

MARY CROSLEY
sworn.

I was at Bradbury's when the mob was there; I was coming by at the time. I saw
James Burn
in the one-pair-of-stairs room; he was looking out at the window and throwing a great many chairs out; when the mob came about the door, he pulled off his hat and cried, No Popery! I saw Price in Lynch's house.

(Price called
Ann Savage
, who had known him upwards of three years;
Elisabeth Woodbridge
, six years; Mr.
Henry Avers
, with whom he lived servant;
William Wiley
, who had known him between ten and eleven years;
Robert Miller
between thirteen and fourteen years;
Jane Castleday
, a great many years;
Ann Useless
, and
John Castleday
, who had known him from his birth, who all gave him a good character.)

(Thompson called
John Holland
, who had known him a dozen years;
Charles Lockwood
, four or five years;
Francis Bailey
, four years; and
Alexander Young
, who had known him two years, who all gave him a good character.)

(Burn called
John Clarke
who had known him ten years; Phabe Fisher five years;
Edward Jesson
, a great many years; and
Edward Hale
, near twelve months, who all gave him a good character.)

PRICE
GUILTY (
Death .)

BURN
GUILTY (
Death .)

THOMPSON
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the First Middlesex Jury before Mr. Justice ASHHURST.

423.
JONATHAN STACEY
was indicted for
that he, together with twenty other persons and more, did, unlawfully, riotously, and tumultuously, assemble, on the 5th of June , to the disturbance of the publick peace, and did begin to demolish and pull down the dwelling house of
Richard Dillon
, against the form of the statute, &c.

JAMES CROSSLEY
sworn.

I am a clock-maker, and live at No. 29, in Christopher's-alley, Moorfields. Mr. Dillon's house is in White's-street, Little Moorfields, between Little-Moorfields and Grub-street
. On the 5th of June, at about nine o'clock in the morning, I took a walk across the fields to see the damages which had been done over night. When I came there I saw the prisoner, with a few boys, first on the roof of the house. It was then about nine o'clock in the morning; there were then many people in the house tearing the inside of the house down. The prisoner began pulling the tiles down and throwing them into the street; after they had cleared a good part of the tiles away, they threw the lead down, and then took each a piece of timber which the lead was nailed to and pushed down the parapet wall, till it was even with the lead, then they shoved the lead of the gutter off into the street; it was a very great weight. I went home then, and returned again in about half an hour. As I was going on an errand to Temple-bar, I saw the prisoner still at work upon the house. The mob were upon several parts of the house throwing and tearing down the timber; I looked at them for the space of an hour. I heard a mob in Grub-street talk of going to demolish an house in Christopher's-alley. I thought it then more prudent to return home, and so I went back again. As I was going home I saw the prisoner at Mr. Dillon's house, taking down a large window, which was difficult to pull down. The principal piece of timber, which went from one wall to the other, four of them took hold of it, the prisoner was one; he took hold of it, and broke the garret room in the middle. One was a barber, another appeared to be a jack tar, and the other was a twine spinner. They took hold of it in the middle and swayed it till they broke it in two, which brought down all the roof together into the street; that was all I saw the prisoner do.

Who gave information about this prisoner? - I went to work in the afternoon, and told my shopmates, that I saw the prisoner Jonathan. We made a joke of it; it came to Mr. Taylor's ears. Mr. Taylor's and Mr. Dillon's houses were both beset.

Did you know the prisoner before? - Yes, I have known him four years. It passed on till Wednesday, then, when I was going to see the ruins, some part of the mob said, d - n it we will have the clock-maker's house down next. That is the man I work with. I sent one of his apprentices to tell him that the mob were going to destroy his house. We sent word we would come into the house one by one backwards; we did so. There were a great many of the mob in the shop; they found we were too strong for them; they did not manage it that night nor the next day. On the Friday it began to be rumoured about, one of the apprentices told our master what I had seen the prisoner do. The neighbours had determined to prosecute all they knew who were concerned. My master asked me if if I had seen the prisoner, and what he was doing; I told him. He said he should be taken up. Some time after that I was called down out of the shop; there were three soldiers; they asked if I was the man who was to show them the prisoner. Then they bid me walk before them, and deliver the prisoner to them. We went towards the skittle-ground the prisoner uses; I went in half a minute before the soldiers. I called to the prisoner, who was lying upon a bench, Jonath an get up, for here are the soldiers coming to take you. He was lying in a narrow place; he endeavoured to make a run; a window pushed him back; the soldiers came up, saw who he was, and took him directly. The soldiers said, is this the man? I could hardly speak. My master said, is this the man? I said yes. Then the soldiers said, deliver him to us; and they took him away.
What day was this? - This was on the 10th, the Saturday I believe.

Had you heard any thing about the reward then? - I had not heard any thing of it till I got to the Artillery Ground, when I was sent for, which was about half an hour after he was taken; I knew him four years before. I am very sure the prisoner is the person.

Prisoner. He offered Mr. Bull, the constable, that he would give him half the reward if he would appear against me - What dress was I in at the time you saw me? - He had a green coat on, and his own hair.
Now he has a wig, has not he? - Yes.
Prisoner. I have witnesses to prove that the evidence did say in their hearing he knew no man at the place.
- BECKET sworn.

Do you know the
Roman Catholick
chapel in Moorfields? - Yes.

Do you know the house adjoining? - It goes in the name of Mr. Dillon but Mrs. Crook pays the taxes; she was housekeeper to them; they did not like to be troubled with it; the taxes are commonly paid in her name, but the house is called Mr. Dillon's; I was in the house at the time the mob came.
Did Mr. Dillon live in it? - Yes, till Saturday the 3d of June; the house was destroyed on the 4th and 5th.
Why did Mr. Dillon leave the house on that day? - Because he had notice the mob would come to destroy it.
In what condition was the house when the mob came? - In perfect good condition. I went out when the mob came in, and on the Tuesday it was quite down to the ground.
Court. This house was generally reputed to be Mr. Dillon's? - It was.
PRISONER'S DEFENCE.

My business called me that way; the mob would not let me pass; conscious I had done no harm I never absconded though I had six days to do it in; the evidence at the Artillery Ground swore he saw me there at ten o'clock, now he swears he saw me there at nine.
For the Prisoner.

WILLIAM RODNOR
sworn.

I believe the prisoner to be a very honest young man; he worked for me some time; he always behaved very honestly and faithfully while he was me; I have known him about ten months; I heard Crossley declare that he knew no man at that place; I believe it was a week ago last Thursday; it was at the Fox in Moorfields.

Crossley. One night after I had been attending here; when I went home my wife told me I had been sent for to the Fox in Moorfields. I went and asked the landlord who wanted me? He said the prisoner's mother, but she was gone; this man and a great many more abused me and called me a
Roman Catholick
dog, and wished my bowels might drop out, and every body's who swore against him; this man asked me if I saw him himself there? I said no, nor any man there; at last they brought out a long paper to prove my religion, which was sold about the street for a penny; and the first question they asked me was, what was paid for absolution?
Was you talking about Dillon's house when you said you had not seen the prisoner, nor any body else there? - No; the Artillery-house.

JOHN EDGER
sworn.

I think it was last Thursday se'nnight I happened to go into the Fox alehouse, in Moorfields, for a pennyworth of beer; Crossley and two other people were there talking about the prisoner; knowing the prisoner I listened to their conversation. I heard Rodnor ask Crossley if he knew any body who was there? Crossley said, no, he did not know any person there. It exasperated me a little. I said to Crossley how can you be such a villain to swear against this man when you say you know nobody who was there.

Had he sworn against him? - The man had been apprehended before this; I asked him how he could be so base to go and swear against this poor fellow when he did not see him there? He did not know directly what answer to make me; presently after he said, there! where do you mean? Why says I the place we are talking about; it was not the Artillery-house we were talking about; I did not hear him mention the Artillery-house, it was the place in White's-alley.
Cross Examination.
Was no mention made of the Artillery-house? - Not while I was there; it might be mentioned before I came in; I had no thought of being called here, if I had I might have taken more notice.

This was after the prisoner was apprehended and Crossley had sworn to him? - Yes, when he said there! where do you mean? He seemed very angry; some words ensued on the matter. I thought it an unjust thing; he went away and said he would fix us all; I do not know that he had any right to say so of me.
Court. What did he say when you said they were talking of him? - I believe he was ashamed; he ran out of the house and said he would fix us all.
Counsel for the Crown. Have not you been threatening the witness since he came into court; I have been told you have? - Then you have been told a very false thing.
You shook your head at him? - I may shake my head without any design.

JOHN PETERS
sworn.
I was in the Fox, publick-house, when the evidence came in; the witnesses who have been examined were asking the prosecutor.
Who asked the prosecutor? - Mr. Edger and Mr. Rodnor. Mr. Edger asked Crossley if he had seen him at the place where the riot was? He said no, nor any one whom he knew.
Where did Edger mean? - At a place in Ropemakers-alley.
That is not White's-alley? - White's-alley is a street which turns up in Ropemakers-alley.
Dillon's house was not in Ropemakers-ally? - I do not know where Dillon's house was; that was the conversation between him and us.
Do you know the house which is pulled down in White's-alley? - I cannot say I do.

How came Edger to ask Crossley whether he had seen either of them in Ropemakers-alley? - I cannot say what was the reason of his asking that question; the prosecutor came into the ale-house, the prisoner's mother had sent for him; they were talking of this, how the prosecutor could be so base to take a man up and swear against him without being sure.
Jury. Are you one of those who called Crossley a Papist? - No.
Did your hear him abused and called a Papist? - I do not remember his being called a Papist; there were some high words arose but nothing of abuse.

(The prisoner called
William Orton
who had known him seven years.
John Valentine
eight years. Joseph Syther fourteen years.
Richard Bodear
many years, and Richard Hall who had known him eight years, who all gave him a good character.)

GUILTY (
Death .)
Tried by the First London Jury before Mr. Justice ASHHURST.

424.
LUKE HAND
was indicted for
that he, together with forty other persons and more, did, unlawfully, riotously, and tumultuously, assemble, on the 7th of June
, to the disturbance of the public peace, and did begin to demolish and pull down the dwelling house of
William Gerrard
, against the form of the statute, &c.

ELIZABETH COUCH
sworn.

My husband keeps horses and carts to let out; we live in Pear-Tree-street, in the Parish of St. Luke's
, almost opposite to Mr. Gerrard's. Upon the 7th of June, between ten and eleven o'clock, the mob came by our door; the first person I saw was the prisoner and a man in blue drummer's clothes; the prisoner had an ax over his left shoulder; the mob got very thick to Mr. Gerrard's door. Then the prisoner called shew a book, and a bible was put out; presently after I saw two pannels of the door broke with the thick part of the ax, I believe; I did not see him break any other part of the house; then the mob got in, and the first man I saw at the one-pair-of-stairs window was the prisoner at the bar; he leaned out of the window, waved his hand, and said buzza! all Popery! A very little after that I saw him bring a drawer of linen and books to the window, and he cried again buzza, all Popery. Our house is opposite; our yard adjoins Mr. Gerrard's house; they wanted to burn the things in our yard. I desired they would not, as there were wooden things in the yard. The furniture was thrown out at the windows, the windows were broke, and the wainscoting torn sadly by the side of the windows; and two of the middle pannels were broke. The prisoner, I believe, continued there three quarters of an hour; I did not see him come out but I saw him go down the street with something to burn, but what it was I do not know.
Cross Examination.
How long had you known the prisoner before? - I never saw him before; I knew him because he was so tall.

When did you see him again? - The Monday after in New Prison. My husband said I should go to see if it was the same person I had given a description of him before to my husband, and one Mr. Hawei, that he was a very tall man, and had some defect in his mouth.
Are you sure it was an ax, was it not a bag of tools? - No, it was not a bag of tools, I believe it was an ax.
What sort of hat had he on? - I did not take notice of his hat. I am sure he is the man whom I saw the night of the riot.
Court. What sort of coat had he on that night? - A lightish loose coat.
How came you to take such particular notice of his mouth? - I thought he looked odd with it.
Counsel. Did you see the defect as he went along or when he spoke? - I did not hear him speak.
Can you see a defect of his mouth as you stand there? - Yes, any body may see it if they look at him.
Court. Upon your oath did you not first perceive that defect in his mouth when you saw him in the prison? - No, I saw it first as he came up the street.
When the prisoner came to the window he spoke? - Yes, he cried huzza, all Popery. I did not hear him speak in the street.
Upon your oath is the prisoner the man you saw in Gerrard's house? - Upon my oath I think he is; I know he is.

ALICE BRIDGES
sworn.

I live in Peartree-street. On Wednesday evening, when the mob came there I was standing at my door. The prisoner was the first man I saw; there were a great number of people with him hallooing all up the street; I did not hear what they said; I afterwards saw the prisoner at Mr. Gerrard's one-pair-of-stairs window; he put his hand upon the ledge, and cried out huzza, all popery by G - d. I saw him break the glass of the beauset, and pull the wainscoting out of the window and throw it into the street; he then went to the next window and took the top drawer out of a chest of drawers which was full of linen; and he brought it upon his head to the window, and threw it out and huzza'd; he then threw out a quart bowl full of some thing, and huzza'd. I did not see him afterwards; I am perfectly sure the prisoner is the man; it was near eleven o'clock at night when I saw him; I went afterwards with Mr. Crouch to the prison, and saw him, and I knew him directly by a disfigurement I observed in his teeth.

Was you very near him when you observed that? - Yes, the window was not very high; I was opposite, not above seven or eight yards off. He had a light great coat on quite open, a leathern apron, and he had an ax in his hand. I staid there about ten minutes.
Court. How long was you with this man in the prison? - Not long; he was in the yard; I had no conversation with him; he was talking to a number of persons in the prison.
Upon your oath was not the time you saw him in the prison the first time you observed the defect in his teeth? - No, I observed it when I saw him at the window.

THOMAS MAYES
sworn.
I am a tailor and salesman; I live in Golden-lane. I have known the prisoner four or five years, or more.

Was you in company with him on Thursday the 8th of June? - Wednesday or Thursday, I do not know which, I was at the Crown Alehouse with him in the morning, at about eleven or twelve o'clock, in company with
John Bradoury
, the landlord of the house, and two other persons,
John Lynch
, and a Mr. Barton, a carpenter; there were several others, whom I cannot name. It was I believe the morning after the fire at Mr. Lynch's. The prisoner said he was at the pulling down of all the houses in London and burning them at the fires. I saw him at Lynch's the night before, but did not see him do any thing.
Cross Examination.
Do you know the prisoner? - Yes, very well.
Was he drunk at that time? - No, I do not think he was.
Then he must be mad? - I do not think he is a madman; I think he is a man who knows things very well.
He said he was at the pulling down and burning all the houses in London, how came that to be the subject of conversation? - I cannot say; I heard him say only that.
You saw him at Lynch's doing nothing at all? - Yes.
Counsel for the prisoner. Then you could have contradicted him as to that fact at least.

JOHN BRADBURY
sworn.

I keep a publick-house in Golden-lane. The prisoner was at my house on Thursday, Friday, or Saturday. I do not know which, but it was after Mr. Lynch's and my house were demolished. He said, he had been at all the fires in London. That was all I heard him say; He did not say it to me, he said it to other people.

JOHN LYNCH
sworn.

I was in company with the prisoner at Mr. Bradbury's two or three days after my house was demolished. I did not remark the day. Mayes, the prisoner, and some others were drinking. Mayes and he had some words. The prisoner said he had been at all the fires, and all the houses which had been done. I looked very earnestly at him, but did not recollect seeing him at my house. He said, he had been at all the fires, and pulling down the houses in London. Those were the words as near as I can recollect.
Can you recollect how long this conversation was after the demolishing of your house? - It was the same week. My house was pulled down on the Tuesday; I am sure it was not the Wednesday.
Did he speak as if he had been active in it? - He did not say he had been doing it; he might be a spectator.

EDWARD BEVAN
sworn.

The prisoner came to my house on the 7th of June, about midnight with the mob, he came into the house and said to the mob, there was no Popery there, the house should not come down. He seemed to have the conduct of the mob. I never saw him before. He was brought to me when he was taken, and I said I could swear to him; I am sure he is the man.
PRISONER's DEFENCE.
I do not want to make a long and tedious defence. I am innocent of the things laid to my charge. I hope this court will not convict the innocent by the evidence of persons of notorious bad morals.
For the Prisoner.

RICHARD REYNOLDS
sworn.

The prisoner is a carpenter and joiner; he was at work at Mr. Scott's, on Holbourn-hill, on the 7th of June, with me, from one o'clock till between six and seven when we parted, but where he went I cannot say.

MARY KEMP
sworn.

I live in Crown-court, Golden-lane. The prisoner lodges next door to me. He was at my house on the 7th of June, to the best of my remembrance it was at near eight o'clock. He staid about half an hour, and by the desire of the neighbours he chalked, No Popery on all the shutters in the court. The neighbours said Mr. Murphy's, the sign of the Sun was pulled down. He said, it was sad work.

ANN HAYWARD
sworn.

I am daughter to the last witness; I live at No. 14, Crown-court. The prisoner has lodged with me two years. On the 7th of June he came home about half after seven o'clock, with his tools on his back; he staid about half an hour; then he went out and returned about twelve o'clock.
Was he drunk? - No, I never saw him drunk, he is a very sober man.
Cross Examination.

Was you gone to bed when he came home? - I cannot recollect whether I was or no. My husband was gone to Mr. Langdale's at Holbourn. My husband generally fits up to let him in; I believe I was in bed; I cannot be sure whether I saw him.

JAMES HAYWARD
sworn.

The prisoner has lodged with me between two and three years. On the 7th of June, between ten and eleven o'clock at night, I met him with one
Martin Harrison
, on Snow-hill, coming towards home; I tapped him on the shoulder, and asked him where he was going; he said, home; we stopped about ten minutes at the end of Fleet-market to look at Mr. Langdale's house, which was then on fire, and then came home together. He and Harrison then went out to get a bit of supper; I let them both in between twelve and one o'clock; they lodged at my house. The prisoner is an honest industrious man, never accustomed to stay out late.
Cross Examination.
Was your wife up when you came home? - Yes, and let us in.
Who generally sits up for the prisoner? - He never stays out late, except by chance, then he lets us know.

MARTIN HARRISON
sworn.

I live at No. 74, in Fore street; on Tuesday the 6th of June, the prisoner and I went to Peckham, we supped there at eleven o'clock; then I came home to his lodging, and slept with him that night; I got up in the morning and went to work; about a quarter after seven in the evening on Wednesday, I met him with a bag of tools on his back, he asked me to go home and have a bit of supper with him; when we came to the end of the court, in sight of Murphy's hous e, Murphy's house was very near down, it was between seven and eight o'clock; he made use of an oath and said, Who would have thought they would have pulled his house down! he shook his head and said, Bad work! bad work! we went up the court to his lodging; Mrs. Hayward was quite frightened, and said,

"Mr. Hand, they will certainly come up this court," and she got him to write No Popery on the window-shutters; we staid near half an hour, and then went out to the end of the court; they said the mob were going to pull down Mr. Cassaday's house, which is higher up; we went to Mr. Cassaday's; Mr. Hand said, he hoped they would not pull the house down, he would try to pacify them. The mob came round there twice; they gave the mob beer, and pacified them; we staid to supper, and went home to his lodging a little before twelve; St. Paul's struck remarkably loud as we went down the lane; I observed to him, that St. Paul's struck remarkably loud; he replied, there will be rain. Then we went to his lodging; we saw Mr. Hayward, I believe Mrs. Hayward was in bed, I did not see her, nor ask where she was. My Lord, I forgot to remark, that when we had been at Cassaday's about half an hour, we went to Mr. Langdale's, hearing his house was on fire; the prisoner lives in Union-court; he said his master's house would be burnt down, and he should lose all his tools; we went to Mr. Scott's, as his chest and some of his tools were there; Mr. Scott said there was no danger. We then went to Mr. Woollaston's, and asked if they wanted any help; they said they wanted all they could get; we staid and assisted them about half an hour; I believe it was near ten o'clock when we came away. We then went up to Mr. Cassaday's; we met Mr. Hayward near Mr. Woollaston's, we went with him to Long-lane, and bought a pig's head, or part of a pig's head; Mr. Hayward then went home without us, and we went immediately to Cassaday's, and staid till twelve o'clock.

(On his cross examination, he said he frequently slept with the prisoner when he was out late; that he was constantly with the prisoner that night till twelve; that the prisoner was in no riot; that he (the witness) was a serjeant in the yellows; that he frequently went home with the prisoner, but could not particularly mention any other day when he had done so.)

WILLIAM GERRARD
sworn.

I left my house about eight o'clock, and did not return till the next morning; I left
William Wildman
and
Thomas Travers
in the house.

WILLIAM WILDMAN
sworn.

I was in Mr. Gerrard's house when the mob came; I staid till it was all over; I never saw the prisoner in my life, to my knowledge, till I saw him afterwards in prison. Mr. Gerrard went out between seven and eight o'clock, and left the keys with Mr. Travers and me; we staid in the house till about ten o'clock; then we came out and locked the door, and staid at the door till the mob came; then a tall man came and knocked at the door, but not the prisoner, to my thinking he was a great deal older, he had a thin face, a black beard, a wig on, and he had a light drab frock: that man would have set the house on fire if it had not been for me and some of the neighbours; I did not observe any thing in his hand; he appeared cool, but very resolute to set the house on fire; I told them there was nobody in the house, and then two brewers servants broke two pannels of the door with a pump handle.
Had either of those two, or the tall man, an ax? - I saw an ax, after it was done, in a drummer's hand; that was after they had got the goods down into Goswell-street, and set them on fire.
"On his cross examination he said the
"door was broke open about twenty minutes
"after eleven o'clock; that when they had
"broke the pannels, somebody said Mr.
"Travers had the key; that they got it
"from him, opened the door, and went in;
"that he saw the drawers thrown out; that
"there were several persons in the one-pair-of-stairs;
"that one leaned out and said,
"Huzza! all Popery! but he did not know
"who it was; that he did not see any one
"person there that he knew; that if the
"prisoner had been there, and taken an active
"part, he thought he must have seen
"him."

THOMAS TRAVERS
sworn.

I live in Pear-tree-street; I had the key of the street-door and beer cellar left with me; Mr. Gerrard left the house about eight o'clock; we were moving some things out; we illuminated the house, and hung a blue flag out; Mr. Wildman and I came out, and were at the door when the mob came up; they knocked at the door two or three different times; there was a tallish man in a smock frock, which covered his clothes, and he had a wig; there were only two tall people, one in a drummer's dress, the other a shorter man; first they knocked at the door, then they began to break the pannels; I cannot say what with, but I afterwards found a pump-handle in the house.

When they first came up did you observe any of them to have an ax? - I did not, indeed my flurry was very great; Mr. Couch informed me a person was taken up, and desired me to go with him to see him; I said I could not be certain to the person, I think the man that was there was something shorter than the prisoner, and had a wig; I do not think the prisoner is the man. When they had broke the pannels of the door I resigned the key to a Mr. Berry, and went away to a relation's of Mr. Gerrard's, to enquire for him; when I returned they were bringing out the goods to burn in Goswell-street.
Was Berry so situated as to observe the people who were there? - He was at the door, and opened it to let them in.

WILLIAM JONES
sworn.

I am apprentice to Mr. Wood, a watch-maker, in Norman-street, Old-street; I went on Wednesday the 7th of June to see Mr. Gerrard's house, which I heard was pulled down; they were taking things to the fire; some men were beating on the bottom of a kettle for the mob to go with them; they said they would go to Golden-lane; there was a tall man and another with an ax, but neither of them were the prisoner; I did not see the prisoner there.
Do you know the prisoner? - No, I never saw him to speak to him till I saw him in the bail-dock.

ABRAHAM HUBBART
sworn.

I belong to Mr. Wood, a watch-maker, in Norman-street; on Wednesday the 7th of June, at about eleven or twelve o'clock, I went to Mr. Gerrard's house, they were just pulling it down; I then went into Goswell-street to the fire of Mr. Gerrard's goods; I saw several people carry goods, but do not remember any person in particular; there was a tall man in a white coat and his own hair, but I think he was older than the prisoner.

(The prisoner, in his defence, called
Richard Gilbert
,
John Cassaday
,
William Kemp
,
Henry Dennis
,
John Frazier
,
Thomas Pearson
,
William Wyley
,
Phoebe Free
,
William Champ
,
Thomas Smith
,
William Scatherwood
,
Mary Kemp
,
Jane Cassaday
, and
Sarah Tinam
, who had all known him for some years, and who gave him a good character.)

JOHN BERRY
sworn.

I am a watch-motion maker. I live opposite Mr. Gerrard's. I was at the door when the mob first came up; there were about six. I went over and expostulated with them; I made an observation on two persons in particular one was a middle sized man, in the habit of a drummer, the other was a tall man, in a drayman's jacket; the same man I had before seen at the Sun. I did not observe any other tall man; I spoke to the drummer and told him of the impropriety of his conduct. He said, he was forced by the mob to come there; he had a bar of iron or something headed with iron with which he broke the frames of the sash and the glass in the one-pair-of-stairs room; he broke one of the pannels of the door, and I fetched him the key from Mr. Travers to prevent him doing any further mischief. I talked to him a good deal and told him the hoose belonged to a Protestant but without effect; he seemed to be determined to do all the mischief he could; after the door was broke open I heard a boy ask what books there were? I went up to the one-pair-of-stairs floor with them, and staid with them till they went away. There were in the one-pair-of-stairs boys, in all about seven or eight; they destroyed the glass and window frames, and threw what goods there were into the street.

Do you remember any person in the one-pair-of-stairs window calling out to the mob All Popery here? - Yes; the man in the drummer's jacket did; the man's face, who called out all Popery, was so dirty with the work he was about that I do not think I should know him again.

Jury. You say the man had an iron bar or something headed with iron, was that strait or crooked? - I apprehended it to be an ax; the prisoner is not the person who had it, he has not the most distant resemblance to the man I have been speaking of; the person who did the mischief had larger features and was a taller man; there is so little likeness that I do not think it possible to mistake the one for the other.
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the First Middlesex Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

LUKE HAND
was indicted for
that he, together with forty other persons and more, did, unlawfully, riotously, and tumultuously, assemble, on the 8th of June
, to the disturbance of the publick peace, and did begin to demolish and pull down the dwelling house of
Cornelius Murphy
, against the form of the statute, &c.
(There was not any evidence given on this Indictment.)
NOT GUILTY .

425.
EDWARD MILLER
was indicted for
that he, together with forty other persons and more, did, unlawfully, riotously, and tumultuously, assemble, on the 8th of June
, to the disturbance of the publick peace, and did begin to demolish and pull down the dwelling house of
John Lynch
, against the form of the statute, &c.

ROBERT REMINGTON
sworn

I keep carts and horses now; I live in Hartshorn-court, Golden-lane. I was at Mr. Lynch's house when the mob attacked it, on Tuesday night the 6th of June, at about a quarter after ten o'clock, the mob went in at the back door, and threw every thing out of the shop; then they went up stairs and threw out the furniture, and pulled down part of the house; then they took the things into Old-street Road and burnt them. I saw the prisoner several times take the things from the door and carry them to Old-street Road to have them burnt; he helped to throw the goods out at the window before he took them away. The mob went from thence to Mr. Bradbury's; that was after twelve o'clock; I saw the prisoner take a paper out of a chest, which was carried to be burnt; I thought it was a paper of halfpence. I said to him, about half an hour after, you have got a crown-paper of halfpence. He said it was only a paper of buttons.

JAMES YOUNG
sworn.

I live at No. 37, in Old-street. On the evening of the 6th of June, about nine o'clock, I saw the mob gathering round the turnpike. I went up to them and saw the prisoner come from Golden-lane with some fire in one hand and a bed-tick, or a piece of a bed-tick, in the other; I saw him put the light under it; I heard Mr. Lynch's house was pulling down; his goods were bringing up at this time. I have known the prisoner exceeding well a great many years; he carries garden-stuff about the street.

BENJAMIN BLAKE
sworn.

I am a tin-plate-worker, and likewise a constable. I went with Crouch and Hawes, two other constables, to a room where I was told the prisoner lodged in the house of Mrs. Blank, in the Wooden-World, behind Golden-lane; there I found a tea-kettle, a blanket, and twenty buttons, and two tea-kettles in the passage of the outside on the door; the prisoner was not at home at the time.
Young. The prisoner told me about six weeks ago that he lodged at Mrs. Blank's, in the one-pair-of stairs. (The things were produced in court by the constables.)

(
John Crouch
confirmed the testimony of the last witness and added that there was some apparel in the room which he had seen the prisoner wear.)

JOHN LYNCH
sworn.

My house in Golden-lane was attacked by the mob on the evening of the 6th of June; it was in good repair when they attacked it; when they left it the wainscoting and frames of the windows were beat out. (looks at the buttons) I know these buttons; they were in a drawer when the mob came; they came off a coat of my son's. I cannot swear to the blanket; but I can to one of the tea-kettles.
PRISONER's DEFENCE.

The first time I had a hearing before the justice that gentleman would not swear to me; the second time they fetched Lynch and Bradbury and neither of them would swear to me; Crouch said, now, you dog, I will be revenged of you. He ran and fetched this Remmington; and he asked Crouch, as he was leaning against the place, how much money am I to have for swearing.
(Crouch being interrogated as to the reward, said, if it came legally to him he should accept of it.)

(The prisoner called
Thomas Stocks
who had known him from a child.
Richard Monday
seven or eight years, and
George Stock
fourteen or fifteen years who all gave him a good character.)
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the First Middlesex Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

EDWARD MILLER
was indicted for
stealing a copper tea kettle, value 2 s. a blanket, value 8 s. and twenty metal buttons, value 2 s. the property of
John Lynch
.

ROBERT REMINGTON
sworn.

When Lynch's house was demolished, as the prisoner was carrying things to burn, I saw him have a paper in his hand; I could not see what was in it. I said to him he had picked up a paper of halfpence. He said, it was nothing but a paper of buttons; the prisoner lodges in the Wooden-World, in Bell-yard, at Mrs. Blank's.

(
John Crouch
, the constable, produced the buttons which he deposed he found in a one-pair-of-stairs room in Mrs. Blank's house.)
Jury. My lord, we do not think the evidence sufficient to convict the prisoner.
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the First Middlesex Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

426.
MARY STRATTON
was indicted for
stealing two blankets, value 10 s. a cotton window curtain, value 2 s. a silk cloak, value 10 s. a linen apron, value 2 s. a linen cap, value 6 d. and a muslin apron, value 2 s. the property of
Christopher Conner
, June 8th .

ANN CONNER
sworn.

I am the wife of
Christopher Conner
; he did keep the sign of the Red Lion, in Black Lyon-yard, Whitechapel
. On the 7th of June, in the evening, when our house was demolished, I saw the prisoner go in and out of the house, and bring out some things, part of which I have here (producing the apparel mentioned in the indictment.) She lodged in a room of mine, opposite our house. I thought she was going to save them for me; I followed her to the stairs; there she met
Mary Pickott
and gave them to her and bid her take them to her own house. Pickott said, what must I do with them? Then the prisoner said, carry them to-morrow morning to pawn, and you shall have half what they fetch. I went to her on the Friday following and asked her whose the black cloak and the other things I saw her have were? I told her I would be obliged to her to tell me. She said, yes, She would blow
Mary Pickott
for she had not given her half the money. She gave me a direction to Pickott. I went to Pickott; she gave me the things out of pawn on my paying for them; the blankets cost me sixteen shillings about six months ago.

MARY NESBIT
sworn,
I saw the prisoner come out of Conner's house with some things in her lap; I followed her a little way, but the mob was so great I could not follow her far.
PRISONER's DEFENCE.
Nesbit was in my room and wanted to lie there with a man.
Nesbit. It was my husband.

Prisoner. No, it was not; I would not let her lie there, and she went down stairs and picked up these things and put them in my room. Mrs. Conner came up and had what things I had saved, and the next day she asked me if I knew any thing of her cloak? I said, I did not. She went to this girl's house and found the things, and she said I gave them to her. I know nothing of it.

GUILTY .
Imp. 6 months .
Tried by the First Middlesex Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

426.
ANN SHERWOOD
was indicted for
stealing a child's linen shift, value 3 s. two linen gowns, value 5 s. a stuff petticoat, value 1 s. a pair of men's leather shoes, value 3 s. a linen handkerchief, value 1 d. and a cheque apron, value 2 s. the property of
John Hill
, June 19th .

CHARLES TOWNSEND
sworn.

On Monday was three weeks, as I was going to work, Sarah Hill, the prosecutor's wife called out, stop that woman, she has stole my things! I followed the prisoner and stopped her in Penny-field, Poplar, with the things mentioned in the indictment, in her apron. She said they were her sister's. I brought her and them back to Mr. Hill's.
(They were produced in court and deposed to by the prosecutor.)
PRISONER's DEFENCE.
I leave myself to the mercy of the court.

GUILTY .
W .
Tried by the First Middlesex Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

427.
EDWARD M'CLOUD
was indicted for
stealing a wooden cask, value 2 s. and five gallons of English geneva, value 25 s. the property of
Richard Hooper
and
William Hooper
, June 27th .

RICHARD HOOPER
sworn.

I live at the Cross Keys-Inn, St. John's-street
, there is a communication from the inn into Charter-House-lane. On the 27th of June I saw the prisoner going out into Charter-House-lane with this cask of geneva. I followed him and stopped him; he trembled and dropped the cask.

CHARLES NAYLOR
sworn.
I live at Mr. Hooper's; while I was on the necessary, I saw the prisoner take a six gallon cask and go out; when I came out my master had him in possession.
PRISONER's DEFENCE.
Going through this place, a young man asked me to help him with this cask.

GUILTY .
Fined 1 s.
Tried by the First Middlesex Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

428, 429, 430, 431.
SARAH WEGION
,
JANE GOFF
,
HANAH DYALL
and
MARY the wife of William BLANK
were indicted, the three first for
stealing a copper pot, value 5 s. two copper tea kettles, value 3 s. an iron vice, value 2 s. 24 lb. weight of lead, value 18 d. a linen sheet, value 2 s. two cloth coats, value 10 s. two cloth waistcoats, value 10 s. two pair of cloth breeches, value 5 s. a brass fender, value 3 s. a brass skellet, value 1 s. and two bed ticks, value 5 s. the property of
John Lynch
, June 7th
; the other for
receiving part of the above goods, well knowing them to be stolen .
ROBERT REMINGTON sworn.

I was at Mr. Lynch's house when it was attacked by the mob. I saw
Hannah Dyall
take a blanket and sheet, and two red curtains from Mr. Lynch's door, and carry them through Playhouse-yard.

MARY CROSSLEY
sworn.

I saw Dyall take a sheet, two red curtains, and a tin kettle from a heap of things by Lynch's house. Goff took half a ticking; of a bed, a whole ticking, and a counterpane, she sold them to
Mary Blank
for five shillings, and a copper pot and two copper tea-kettles, for two shillings; that was the 7th of June; about seven in the morning. She took them from the house about ten o'clock at night.
Sarah Wegion
helped her. Goff and Wegion told me they had sold them. The brass fender and skellet were found in Wegion's ground.
Goff. Did you see me take any property from Mr. Lynch's? - That cloak.

JAMES COUCH
, a Constable, sworn.
I found two tea-kettles in the house of Mrs. Blank on the landing-place, up one-pair-of-stairs.

BENJAMIN BLAKE
sworn.

I found the fender and skellet in Wegion's yard; they were underground. I dug them up in consequence of an information. She lives in the Wooden World, Bell-court, Golden lane. The garden is fenced with wooden rails. We found the rug on Goff's bed.
(They were produced in court.)

JOHN LYNCH
sworn.
I cannot swear to the fender, I can to the rug; it was lost the 6th of June, after ten at night. The skellet is my property.
WEGION's DEFENCE.
I know nothing of what she has laid to my charge.
GOFF's DEFENCE.

She said at the Artillery-ground, if I would back her evidence, she would give me half the reward. She said she had done the thing that was very wrong, and unless I would back her oath she should be ruined. A woman who lodged in the house brought them up about nine in the morning, and desired to leave them. She came and opened the bundle, and said it was not worth much, I might throw it on my child's bed; I took it not knowing she came dishonestly by it.

ALL FOUR
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the First Middlesex Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

432.
ANN GRANT
was indicted for
stealing a black silk laced cloak, value 10 s. and a linen shift, value 3 s. the property of
Timothy Farrell
, July 3d .
(The prosecutor was called, but not appearing, the court ordered his recognizance to be estreated.)
NOT GUILTY .

433.
JOHN BENNETT
was indicted for
stealing a silver watch, value 3 l. two gold lockets, and a diamond ring , the property of
Charles Bremham
, June 27th .

Mr.
CHARLES BREMHAM
sworn.

I came from Oxford on Tuesday the 27th of June. I put up at an inn in Piccadilly, and went to see a friend in the city; he was going to the masquerade. I was coming back from the city to Piccadilly; my friend was going to Carlisle-house
; I went with him to put him towards the door; when he got near the step of the door, I put my hand upon his shoulder, and said, good night. When I thought to return back I felt some one in the crowd pressing violently on the small of my back, and he cried get on, get on, as if an ox or a carriage was coming; I saw nothing to justify this. I felt a hand at the flap of my waistcoat, taking my watch out of my pocket. As I saw the hand come from my fob, I catched the man by the waistcoat and said he had stolen my watch; he put his hand over the shoulder of a man who stood before him; I called a constable and told him the prisoner had taken my watch and given it to another person. We secured him and took him to the watch-house, there was nothing but a few half pence, a knife, and a bit of silk, found upon him.
PRISONER's DEFENCE.
I never had the watch.

Prosecutor. I think it my duty to say some thing for the prisoner. There is but one evidence against him, that is me; I may be mistaken. When the watch was taken from me it was eleven o'clock at night, in the dark, and in a crowd. The same voice which cried, get on, as it hurried me on, might have burried another person. If the jury bring him in guilty, I hope they will recommend him to mercy.
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the First Middlesex Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

434.
ELISABETH HUMPHREYS
was indicted for
stealing a blue linen apron, value 1 s. and 28 lb of cherries, value 4 s. the property of
Hugh Wright
, June 29th .
(The prosecutor was called but not appearing, the court ordered his recognizance to be estreated.)
NOT GUILTY .

435.
GEORGE RAWLIN otherwise RAWLINGS
was indicted for
receiving three trusses of clover, value 3 s. five trusses of hay, value 5 s. two trusses of straw, value 10 d. and a peck of beans, value 6 d. the property of
Joseph Bolden
(for the stealing of which Chapman was convicted in April session) well knowing them to have been stolen , January 28th .
(A copy of the record of the conviction of Chapman was produced in court and read.)

JOSEPH BOLDEN
sworn.

On the 28th of January I saw a parcel of clover, in a lost belonging to one
Giles Ray
, which I believe by the circumstances to be mine, it was a part of the rick which stood to the very last; there were a great many oats intermixed with it. I sent for some of the last load from London, and compared them, and it exactly resembled that which I saw at Ray's; I believe it to be mine; my clover had been missed about two days before.

JAMES TALBOT
sworn.

I work for Mr. Bolden, at London Style farm, at hay-binding, and any thing he has got to do; I missed clover out of the rick-yard several times. On the 28th Mr. Bradmore informed us some had been carried over the road. We had a mistrust where it went to, and I went the next morning with Joseph Bedding to Mr. Rawlins the King
George III
's Head a publick-house opposite London-Style Farm. We found two trusses of second-cut clover in his garden, about the middle as near as I can guess.
Was Rawlins there? - I saw him as I went up the yard.

Have you any reason to know whose clover it was? - Only by the confession of Chapman before the justice. The prisoner brought it back and put it in the place it came from, and d - d Chapman's eyes for bringing it there.
Was the prisoner present when Chapman confessed he carried it there? - I cannot say whether he was there or not.

JOSEPH BEDDING
sworn.
I went with the last witness to the prisoner's garden, and found the clover. The prisoner said he did not know who brought it there.

WILLIAM BRADMORE
sworn.

On the 27th of January about half after five in the morning, I saw a man go a-cross the road with a bundle of some thing upon his back from Mr. Bolden's yard, to King
George III
's Head. It appeared to me to be a bundle of second-cut clover. I was about twenty yards from him when I saw him. I went to the rick which I thought he came from, and saw some fresh second-cut clover dropped off the rick. I saw him go up a passage with it behind the prisoner's house. I went behind the prisoner home and saw some fresh second-cut clover lying on the bench.
Who carried it to Rawlins's? - I do not know the man.

JOHN STEVENS
sworn.
I am a constable of the parish of Acton. I had a warrant, and took Chapman for stealing the clover on the 29th of March.

THOMAS WATSON
sworn.

On the 28th of January, between seven and eight o'clock, I stood at the gate by Mr. Bolden's yard. I heard Chapman say to the prisoner, do not let it stay here, take it away. I do not know what they were talking about. Rawlins came out, and went up his yard, and then came by me with a truss of hay, and put it into Mr. Bolden's yard; he said Chapman had left some hay there, and it should go to where it came from; that he could not think what he left it there for.

GILES RAY
sworn.

I am a gardener. I have known the prisoner two or three years. I never knew but he was a very honest man. I had two or three bundles of hay of him. I gave him the full value for it. I do not know where he had it.
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the First Middlesex Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

436.
GEORGE BRADLEY
was indicted for
burgariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
William Jones
, on the 13th of May , about the hour of ten in the night, and stealing thirteen yards of black silk lace, value 30 s. the property of the said William .

WILLIAM JONES
sworn.

I keep a shop in Tottenham-court road
. On Saturday the 13th of May, about half after ten at night, I was in the shop; I heard a pane of glass break; they had fastened the shop-door on the out-side with a cord; a person who saw the prisoner run from the window, pursued him, and brought him back in about two minutes; his finger was cut, and bled very much; he was searched, but nothing found upon him.

MATTHEW WEST
sworn.

Coming down Tottenham court road, on the 13th of May, about half after ten o'clock, I heard a window break. I looked across the way, and saw the prisoner run. I ran after him, and made a blow at him, at the top of Tavistock-street; he popped his head down, and ran back again down the mews in Tavistock-street, there I knocked him down and secured him, and brought him back to the prosecutor's house; there was nothing found upon him. I saw nobody else run from the window; his finger was off before, the stump was cut with the glass.

Jones. The lace mentioned in the indictment was lost out of the window. I saw it about half an hour before. There were thirteen yards at half a crown a yard; it was on a card; it was picked up by a gentleman.
JOHN BROWN sworn.

On the 13th of May, between ten and eleven o'clock, coming down Tottenham-court road, I saw a mob at the prosecutor's house, and in Tavistock-street I found this card of lace (producing it). I took it back to the prosecutor's; he said it was his property.
(The lace was deposed to by the prosecutor.)
PRISONER's DEFENCE.
Coming down Tavistock-street three boys ran by me, a gentleman laid hold of me, and said I had stolen a piece of lace. I know nothing of it.

NOT GUILTY of breaking and entering the dwelling-house, but guilty of stealing the lace .
N.1 Year .
Tried by the First Middlesex Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

437.
ABRAHAM DANSON
was indicted, for
that he, together with forty other persons and more, did unlawfully, riotously, and tumultuously, assemble on the 6th of June , to the disturbance of the publick peace, and did begin to demolish and pull down the dwelling-house of the Right Honourable
William Earl of Mansfield
against the form of the statute, &c.

SUSANNAH MOORE
sworn.

I was in Bloomsbury-square
on the morning of the 17th of June, with Mr. Danson, Mr. Keene, and Mr. Moore; a great mob were throwing furniture out of the window. I saw Mr. Danson assist forty or fifty more in pulling down the rails; as he was pulling them down he fell backwards. I knew him before. He brought out two bottles of wine, and gave them to Mr. Key, and bid him carry them home to his, the prisoner's, house.
"On her cross examination she said, that
"the prisoner went with her, and Mr.
"Keene; that she and her husband were
"taken up, and charged with having been
"concerned in the riot, but that no prosecution
"was carried on against them;
"that she was told, before she made any
"discovery as to the prisoner, that he had
"charged her with taking wine out of the
"house, and likewise had charged her
"husband, who had been taken up; that
"when they first set out she did not know
"they had any intention of going to Bloomsbury,
"but hearing there was a fire they
"went to see it as innocent spectators; that
"they drank some wine in Bloomsbury-square;
"that she did not see the prisoner
"in the house; she further said, that the
"prisoner called at their house; that from
"thence they went to the prisoner's house;
"that when the witness signified her intention
"of going with them, Danson said it
"was not a place for women to go to, but
"the witness said, if her husband went she
"would go."

GEORGE KEENE
sworn.

I went out with Mr. Danson. Going across Holborn I lost my company. When I got to Bloomsbury-square I stood there ten or twenty minutes. Danson came up, and gave me two bottles of wine, and desired me to carry them to his house; this was a quarter of an hour after I had first parted with him. I left the two bottles at the Coach and Horses; two or three days after I took one to Danson, and the other I have myself at this time; when I went down to Danson's I gave the bottle to him; when I returned to the square I observed the prisoner there with Mr. and Mrs. Moore. I was not taken up upon this affair. I was last in the square, and set out from Danson's in Clare-market, and not from Moore's. I did not see the prisoner do any act while I was there.
Prisoner. I leave my defence to my counsel.
For the Prisoner.

ABRAHAM LONGBOTTOM
sworn.

I am a fireman to the Westminster-office; I have been a fireman twenty years. I have known Mr. Danson these twelve years. When Sir
John Fielding
's house was on fire I went there; after that fire was out we went to Lord Mansfield's, when we came there I saw Mr.
Abraham Danson
; he said namesake I am glad to see you, here is great confusion and distress, and I will assist you all that lies in my power. I said be so kind as to take the hose and assist all you can; he did take it, and did as I desired him to the fire-plug; he screwed them on, and carried them to Lord Mansfield's house, to go down into the area for the water to pour in. We were not permitted to play the engine. We put the engine into the carriage by the fireman's order, and drew it round the next street. This was, I believe, about half after four o'clock.

Did he appear there as a person active in doing mischief, or as one very desirous to prevent it? - He prevented it as far as I saw; when we had orders to put the engine into the carriage he assisted us to lift it in; after that he and I went into a publick-house, and had each a glass of Pepperment a piece; then he shook hands with me and departed.

Counsel for the crown. All was done before that time; the house was then on fire, was it not? - Yes it was, before we had the alarm. I have known him thirteen or fourteen years; he kept a publick-house in the Borough-market before he removed to this end of the town. I never heard any thing against his character.
How long did you see the prisoner before you parted with him? - He was with me an hour and an half.

THOMAS LARKIN
sworn.
I went with Mr. Danson to Bloomsbury-square; it was near two when I got there.

And with Moore? - No; I do not know any other person that I went with but Mr. Danson; we staid there a considerable time; at last an engine came. Mr. Danson said, there is a man come with an engine, who I know well; I wish it was in my power to assist him; this is the man that came with the engine (Longbottom.)
Had Danson before that done any act whatsoever to encourage the mob? - I saw none.

And you was with him? - I might be five or ten minutes now and then from him. I saw him go up to his acquaintance, and endeavour to assist him; the mob did not seem as if they would let the engine go to work. I drew back, and did not see Danson any more till after the engine was going to be put upon a carriage, then I saw him assisting Mr. Longbottom to put it on. We went from thence; we had not got far from the house before we met a man who looked like a porter with some wine; he had, I suppose, four bottles in each hand, and one tucked under each arm; he said, will you relieve me from my burthen, if not I must break a bottle; he had not got the word out of his mouth before he dropped one. I believe Mr. Danson did release him from the two bottles under his arm. The man said I will come back in a very few minutes and fetch them; this was between three and four o'clock.
Did you see any body else in Danson's company? - No; not that I know of my own knowledge.

From the time he came into the square you came in with him, and staid till he went away, did you ever see him pulling at the rails of Lord Mansfield's house, with an intent to pull them down? - No, never; whenever I saw him he never attempted such a thing as that.
If he had been so active you must have seen it? - I think I must.
Cross Examination.
Did you take any of this load of wine from the poor man that was so encumbered? - I did not.
Then he did it as a serv ice to the man to take two bottles from him? - He asked him to do it.
Did he put them into his pocket? - I cannot say, I left him behind me there.
Were the iron palliadoes pulled down while you staid there? - I head a snapping and cracking, whilst I was there, like something of the kind.

Who and what are you? - My name is
Thomas Larkin
.
That is a very good travelling name; what business are you? - Clerk to a wharfinger at Smart and Dyce Key.
How long have you been clerk to a wharfinger? - Since last Christmas.
Because the last time I had the honour to see you, you was clerk to an attorney. You are the same man that came to be bail in the King's Bench for 3000 l. and was rejected? - I was.
Was not you clerk to an attorney then? - No.
Was not you clerk to Mr. Bowstead? - No.
You served notices and writs for him? - Yes.
How long? - Not since last November, then I left Mr. Bowstead.
The long vacation is a dead time, and you amused yourself with serving writs? - I never served writs, I carried notices of bail.
Mr. Bowstead has a great deal of business in the bail way. You used to carry notices for bail, and offer yourself for bail perhaps? - Offer myself for bail?
When the bail did not appear perhaps? - I beg no such reference may be made.
You did that for nothing, merely for amusement? - I intended to have served a clerkship to an attorney.
What, at your time of life? - Yes.
What, is a clerk to an attorney so much preferable to the wharfinger business? Why did you not prosecute it? - I found my abilities were not sufficient to carry it on.
Had you, before you was rejected as bail, determined not to be clerk to an attorney? - The rejection made no kind of difference to me.
I only ask you the question about the time when you determined not to be clerk? - Before then.
Then you was not with Mr. Bowstead at that time? - Not at all.
And not clerk to him in any respect then?
In no respect whatever.
When did you offer to be bail? - In the last term.
And you are now clerk to a wharfinger, are you? - Yes.

WILLIAM BLICK
sworn.
I have known the prisoner a year and a half, he was a servant of mine, I never heard any but a good character of him.

JOHN DUKE
sworn.

I have known Danson about seven years; he has as honest a character as any I ever heard in my life. I was at his house the Monday after Lord Mansfield's house was destroyed. Some officers came to enquire after him; he was not at home. When they first came he was informed of it by his wife. He said,
"Now I am come home I will stay and see what these people want with me."
Cross Examination.
Did these people leave their business? - No.

(
John Levinge
, who had known him six years; Kendall, two years; Hemmings, two years;
Thomas Martin
and
John Stevens
, between six and seven years, all gave the prisoner a good character.)

EDWARD LUCAS
sworn.

I am a cornchandler, I know nothing of this affair, only I heard Mrs. Moore say, an hour ago, that she should not have appeared against the prisoner, but that if he was not convicted she was afraid he would impeach her and Mr. Moore in something.
Cross Examination.
You were not subpoenaed here as a witness? - No.
Was any person present at this conversation? - Another person was by. I asked him what he was doing here.
Was this conversation in court? - It happened at the door here, before the prisoner came to the bar.
Are you acquainted with her? - I do not know; I have been at the house where she used to sell Sevinge; she has seen me there, that was all the acquaintance I had with her.
To Mrs. Moore. Have you heard what this person says? - Yes; it is very false.
Lucas. That is the man (Keene) who saw me speak to her.
Keene. I did not observe him speak to her, nor see him near her.

Counsel for the crown to Keene. Is Mr.
Lucas
an acquaintance of Mr. Danson's? - No.
Lucas. I have no acquaintance with him.
Counsel for the crown to Lucas. What brought you here? - I came along with Mr. Blick.
Counsel for the prisoner. And you are a stranger to Danson? - Yes.
Counsel for the prisoner to Keene. Mr. Lucas did speak to you, did he not? - He did, and might speak to the woman, but I did not observe him.
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the Second London Jury before Mr. Justice ASHHURST.

rs.p:
Dennis Rearden
, for the murder of his wife, was executed at Tyburn, on Monday July the 3d.

William Macdonald
,
Charlotte Gardiner
, and
Mary Roberts
were executed on Tower-hill,
William Brown
in Bishopsgate street, and
William Pateman
in Coleman street, on Tuesday the 11th of July.

Thomas Taplin
and
Richard Roberts
were executed in Bow-street, and
James Henry
on Holborn-Hill, on Wednesday the 12th of July.

Enoch Flemine
was executed in Oxford-Road, and
Christopher Plumbley
at Tyburn, on Thursday the 13th of July.

John Gamble
was executed at Bethnal-Green,
Samuel Solomons
in Whitechapel, and
James Jackson
in the Old-Bailey, on Thursday the 20th of July.

Thoman Price
,
James Burn
, and
Benjamin Waters
were executed in Old street, opposite Golden-lane,
George Staples
and
Jonathan Stacey
in Moorfields on Friday the 21st of July.

Charles Kent
, and
John Gray
were executed in Bloomsbury-square,
Thomas Kelly
,
Andrew Gray
and
James Earls
at Tyburn on Saturday the 22d of July.
